Italy's erratic defence looks set to face its toughest test of the Six Nations so far when it travels to Dublin to face Ireland on Saturday.

The Azzurri have conceded 123 points in their first three matches - more than any other team in the tournament - and their inability to maintain any kind of momentum in the opposite 22 has cost them dearly.

They shipped in four tries in the first half against England last time out, and had actually scored more points than their opponents at one stage of the match before capitulating in the second half.

Defence coach Fabio Roselli acknowledges that his side must improve if Italy are to have any chance of winning in Dublin, but he is struggling to identify exactly what is going wrong.

"We're trying to figure it out, it's certainly a concern," he said.

"When your defensive organisation is not at the necessary level, it becomes difficult to win games.

"We're working on resetting our defence, especially in training. This week we're going to work on getting our defence back into shape to be more effective."

Italy have won just one of their last 19 Six Nations matches and their overall record of 18 losses and two draws in 20 matches tells its own story.

Conor O' Shea's side have never really been in contention for the title but they will at least target improving on their record haul of three victories in 2015.

And with trips to Scotland and England still to come after this weekend, Roselli knows the time is now for his side to start building some momentum.

"This is our fourth game, so we have a lot of things to work on and improve," he added.

"The campaign is not over, we still have three games to go and even though the maths says it will be difficult to win the Six Nations, we're going to go ahead and work on improving our performance."

A lawsuit claiming Aaliyah's death resulted from negligence can proceed, but allegations targeting her uncle, Blackground Records founder Barry Hankerson, have been dismissed, according to court documents obtained by ABC News. 

The singer's mother, Diane Haughton, and brother, Rashad Haughton, filed a wrongful death lawsuit in 2021 against Hankerson and others, alleging that Aaliyah's death resulted from a "negligent pyrotechnic stunt" that caused her to suffer burns during a video shoot in the Bahamas in 2001. The singer was killed in a plane crash at age 22 as she returned to the United States from the video shoot. 

The lawsuit accused Hankerson of failing to ensure his niece's safety while "acting in an entirely unreasonable, negligent, and reckless manner" as a manager and executive producer of the music video for her single, "Rock the Boat." 

Hankerson -- who founded Blackground Records, which released Aaliyah's music -- denied the allegations, claiming he had no involvement in the video shoot. 

In December, Hankerson filed a motion to dismiss the lawsuit, which a judge granted in part last week, dismissing claims against him. 

"Mr. Hankerson is fully confident that he will be vindicated once the full facts of the case come out at trial," attorney Paul Saputo III said in a statement to ABC News. "He has always and continues to mourn the loss of his niece Aaliyah." 

The wrongful death lawsuit is scheduled for trial in September.

In addition, the government announced plans to spend $14bn on infrastructure projects such as ports and railways, as well as boosting spending on education by $2.6bn.

Robert Williams will remain as chief executive of British Gas owner Centrica despite a dispute with the company's biggest shareholder.

The 62-year-old had said he would step down unless Centrica amended its "unacceptable" £610,000 (US$730,000) retirement package.

But the firm's board has decided to accept his request to stay in post.

Mr Williams had asked the board to guarantee his bonus and entitlements despite his planned departure.

The company had said it could not afford the payments as it battled higher energy prices and a government price cap on tariffs.

But it reversed its position after talks with Mr Williams and the company's three major shareholders - Aviva, Royal London and Phoenix Group.

"The board has agreed to proceed with the payment of certain benefits to Robert Williams, which are consistent with his employment contract," Centrica said in a statement.

"This decision was made in the context of the group's ongoing dialogue with its larger shareholders, with a view to maintaining shareholder support for the company's strategy."

Under the terms of his departure, Mr Williams - who has led the firm since 2016 - will remain in post until a successor is appointed.

He will be entitled to his full salary until then along with any bonuses and entitlements.

Mr Williams had asked the company to pay him a £1.5m "basic salary continuation" payment until November this year, with further payments until the end of August 2023.

He also wanted an estimated £4.1m in pension payments to be paid, citing his "outstanding 12 years of service" to the company.

But the board had said paying the estimated £5.6m in bonuses and pension payments was "not affordable" or "commercially prudent" amid the current economic outlook.

Mr Williams had threatened to take the matter to the Centrica pension trustee and, if necessary, to court.

Centrica has been struggling with the cost of living crisis, which has left many households unable to afford to heat their homes.

The energy firm has faced criticism over plans to pay out £344m in dividends to shareholders while raising prices for customers.

Fulham manager Roy Hodgson is enjoying the "stimulation" of European football and is happy that his side have been drawn against Roma and Basel in the Europa League.

The Cottagers, who finished sixth in the Premier League last season, face Roma in Italy in the first leg of their play-off on 20 August.

"I love being involved in these types of games, love the challenge," he said.

Hodgson spent seven years managing in Europe, guiding Fulham to the Europa League final in 2010, where they were beaten by Atletico Madrid.

"This is a short journey which we've undergone as a club in the last three years and I include ourselves as managers and coaches in that," he said.

"To go from where we were when we arrived, which was basically in the bottom three, to get into the (Premier League) top six and play in Europe again is a great achievement.

"To go into the draw and see who you're going to play and discover you've got Roma and then Basel, it's not as if we've been given a particularly difficult tie.

"It's still going to be very difficult but of course as a coach and a manager you want to test yourself against the best."

Hodgson believes English clubs are now better prepared for European football, particularly in the early stages of tournaments.

"The experiences that English clubs have had in the last few years, not only in Europe but in the FA Cup and the Carling Cup, they are far better equipped to deal with these situations," he said.

"A lot of the players in our squad have not played in these competitions before so it's a new experience for them. It's one that we're all looking forward to."

Meanwhile, Hodgson has confirmed that he is looking to bring in "two or three" new faces before the start of the Premier League season.

"We're still looking for one or two players and I'm hoping that we can announce something in the next few days," he said.

"It's not going to be easy because a lot of clubs are looking for the same type of players as us. We're looking for players who can improve the squad."

Ireland have won the Six Nations Championship after a nerve-jangling 19-16 victory over England in Dublin.

The hosts scored three tries to England's one, but victory was secured by the Irish half-backs, who scored all their side's points through kicks.

Conor O'Shea's men led 19-9 with 10 minutes left, but Owen Farrell's penalty brought England to within two points and they dominated the closing stages.

However, Ireland managed to see out the game, clinching the title with one round remaining.

It was a remarkable triumph for a team that had not won a match in this year's competition going into the fifth weekend of action.

Ireland's previous victory was a 20-10 win over Australia on 29 November, and they had lost their first four Six Nations matches, including a 57-15 thrashing by England at Twickenham in Round 4.

Their title bid looked to have found a major obstacle when centre Robbie Henshaw went off with a shoulder injury after just three minutes, but his replacement, fit-again Garry Ringrose, scored a try with his first touch.

England, who needed to win to keep their title hopes alive, played with ambition but made a series of uncharacteristic mistakes, with Maro Itoje's looping pass intercepted by Ringrose for the try.

Ireland capitalised on another English error when Johnny Sexton's expertly-angled cross-field kick was collected by Simon Zebo for his side's second try, with the fly-half converting to give his side a 13-3 half-time lead.

England had been limited to three Owen Farrell penalties in the opening 40 minutes, with the first of those coming in the first minute.

The visitors came out firing after the break, and a scrum penalty awarded within sight of the Irish line allowed Farrell to reduce the deficit to just four points.

But Ireland hit back with a penalty of their own when England were penalised for not rolling away, and Sexton made it 16-6.

The fly-half had the chance to extend the lead further but skewed his penalty wide, and England took full advantage to score their first try when Ben Te'o touched down after a superb break from Jonathan Joseph.

Councils prepare to set tax rises

UK local authorities will today set budgets for the coming year, including increases in council tax bills for many residents.

The increases, on average between 5% and 5.5%, are the biggest in a decade following a decision by the government to allow councils to raise taxes to compensate for large cuts in central government funding.

The move has prompted accusations that Chancellor George Osborne is passing on the burden of cuts to households.

The government says it is giving councils greater financial freedom.

The increases vary across the country with some areas such as Dorset and North Yorkshire raising bills by as much as nearly 9%.

Residents in Westminster, which includes the central London area, will face an increase of 7%.

Meanwhile, half of Scotland's councils have set increases at or below the Scottish government's threshold of 3%, with some freezing charges.

Are you happy to pay more?

In England, councils can increase council tax by as much as 2% without a referendum, plus another 2% if they promise to spend the money on social care.

They can also add a further 3% if they judge the finances to be unsustainable - a situation many authorities say they are facing.

Ministers say the changes will give councils the ability to "innovate and improve their services", and come after a period of unprecedented cuts.

But the Local Government Association (LGA), which represents councils in England and Wales, has warned that services will have to be cut back even further unless the government provides more funding.

It says overall funding for councils will have been cut by almost 60% between 2010 and 2020.

The LGA's analysis also suggests that council tax increases for bands D and E - which are occupied by more than two-thirds of households - could be as high as 9.5% in some areas.

It describes the situation as "dreadful" and says it is unfair to place the burden on hard-pressed households.

The BBC's assistant political editor Norman Smith said that with just over a month to go before the Budget, the row over who pays for the public finances was heating up.

"The decision by many councils to put up taxes has turned what the government regarded as a good budget trick into a political problem," he wrote in a blog.

The Liberal Democrats said the increases were "astronomical" and would be a burden on millions of households.

The British Academy of Film and Television Arts (BAFTA) has announced the list of movies that will compete for this year's BAFTA Film Awards. The selected films are:

**_Belfast_** _,_ **_CODA_** _,_ **_Don't Look Up_** _,_ **_Dune_** _,_ **_The Power of the Dog_** _,_ **_West Side Story_**

The films, all of which were nominated for Oscars earlier this year, will compete in various categories, including best film, best director, best actor and actress, and best supporting actor and actress. _Belfast_ received the most nominations with an impressive seven, while _West Side Story_ and _Power of the Dog_ both received eight nominations. 

The awards show will take place on March 13 at the Royal Albert Hall in London and will be hosted by actor and comedian Richard Ayoade.

It is one of the world's biggest technology firms, but Microsoft has revealed that its customers are still being affected by bugs in its Windows operating system.

The US software giant issued an emergency fix for a vulnerability that allows hackers to remotely take control of any Windows computer - desktops, laptops, servers, and even smartphones.

The vulnerability, known as BadTunnel, allows hackers to take control of a machine despite no action by the user.

Microsoft said there was no evidence that the vulnerability, in the way Windows verifies security certificates, had been exploited.

But the software giant issued a fix for the bug on Tuesday after researchers discovered it.

Security experts said the discovery highlighted how difficult it was for software companies to secure their products.

The researchers who discovered the bug are demonstrating their findings at the Black Hat security conference in Las Vegas.

BadTunnel takes advantage of a feature in Windows that allows users to connect securely over the internet, using a technology called VPN (virtual private networking).

VPNs are used by companies to allow employees to connect securely to private corporate networks from outside; but the technology has also been offered to consumers by companies like AT&T in the US and BT in the UK.

The researchers found that by manipulating data packets, a hacker could cancel out the private encryption key normally used to secure data transmitted over a VPN.

That would allow a hacker to see all the data passing between a Windows device and its VPN server - including usernames, passwords and other sensitive information.

And because the hack takes advantage of how Windows verifies security certificates, there is nothing a user could do to stop it.

"The user doesn't have to do anything - just using the computer is enough to be vulnerable," said Marc Maiffret, who discovered the bug along with his colleague, Aaron Portnoy.

The researchers said the vulnerability was likely to affect all versions of Windows, including Windows 7, the soon-to-be-released Windows 8, and Windows Server 2003, 2008 and 2012.

And because VPN features are also built into Windows Phone, the vulnerability also affects Windows smartphones.

"We haven't tested it on phones, but there is no reason why it wouldn't work," said Mr Maiffret.

Microsoft issued a fix for the bug on Tuesday, and said it had not seen any evidence that hackers had exploited the vulnerability.

The BBC's "International Film Award" for 2022 has been won by Russia's submission, "Dear Comrades!" a somber retelling of real events, which the BBC calls a "searing depiction of abuse of power."

The film tells the story of a 1962 mass worker's strike in Novocherkassk, in southern Russia, which ended in violence after troops opened fire on protesters.

It was filmed in Belarus, with the director, Andrei Konchalovsky, saying he couldn't have made the film in Russia because it would have been illegal to criticize Stalinism.

The film was chosen by a jury of 18 people, including the Iranian-American filmmaker Ramin Bahrani and the Philippine actor and producer Angeli Bayani.

The BBC's Fiona Lamdin told the BBC's World Service that "Dear Comrades!" had "really resonated" with the jury.

"The film is a brutal account of what happened, it doesn't shy away from the violence, but it also shows the everyday heroism of those who stood up against oppressive Soviet rule."

The "International Film Award" is in its 17th year and aims to "promote films that tackle global issues and give a voice to those who are not heard".

The 2022 jury includes filmmakers from India, Egypt, Colombia, and the US, as well as actors, writers, and producers from the UK, Bangladesh, France, India, and the US.

T-Mobile has announced that it is launching a new working ecosystem, calling it the "pocket office".

The pocket office is made up of three main components - a mobile phone, a laptop and wearable devices such as a smart watch.

T-Mobile said the ecosystem is designed to help people organise and maximise their productivity.

The operator has partnered with Microsoft and Apple on the project, and offers customers a choice of a free iPhone or Samsung phone, and a free Microsoft or Apple laptop.

The package also includes an Apple Watch or Fossil watch, and a mobile phone plan.

"This is the first time that wearable devices have been included in a mobile workplace service," said Andreas Bauer, senior director of business marketing at T-Mobile.

"And with our superfast 5G network, the possibilities for the mobile workplace are endless."

T-Mobile said the pocket office is aimed at both business customers and consumers looking to organise their personal lives.

Brussels has warned that mobile phone operators may be abusing their dominant position by charging for incoming calls.

The European Commission said it would investigate the practice, already criticised by consumer groups.

Mobile phone firms charge a fee for incoming calls while users are roaming outside their home country.

The commission said it would look at ways to "ensure a smooth and affordable use of mobile phones while travelling abroad".

The investigation could lead to changes in the fees European consumers pay when travelling within the EU.

Last year, the commission carried out a survey to find out whether there was cause to investigate the issue.

It found that 65% of respondents were in favour of abolishing the charge for incoming calls while they were abroad.

Currently, mobile phone operators can charge up to 19 euro cents per minute for incoming calls in the EU.

The commission's survey also revealed wide variations in the prices charged by different mobile phone operators. Incoming calls can cost between 6 and 19 euro cents per minute.

There are also big differences in the price of outgoing calls from one country to another. For instance, calls from Greece to Germany cost 19 euro cents per minute, while the equivalent call from Germany to Greece costs just 6 euro cents.

"We will look at the abusive practices which unfortunately still exist in the EU mobile phone market," said Viviane Reding, the EU's telecoms chief.

"Roaming charges should not be higher than at home, nor should they remain high when volumes increase."

The investigation could take a year.

The mobile phone industry has already been hit by a series of EU rulings on the cost of roaming.

Last month, the European Parliament voted for the complete abolition of roaming charges by 2015.

 Operators have also been forced to slash the cost of making calls while abroad.

Last year, the commission ruled that operators would have to cut the cost of outgoing roaming calls by more than half, to just 3 euro cents per minute, by July this year.

This summer, EU officials will also begin examining the cost of texting while abroad.

A recent survey by the British consumer group, Which?, found that UK mobile phone users were still often unaware that they were paying additional fees for incoming calls while abroad.

Last year, the Office of Fair Trading (OFT) in the UK expressed "serious concerns" about the practice.

A helmet that reads people's brainwaves and lets them control a computer with their thoughts has been developed by Japanese researchers.

The "Brainwave" cap detects electrical activity in the brain caused by concentration and relaxation.

Users can perform simple tasks, such as turning a switch on and off, by thinking about it.

The device could be used to help people with movement disorders control equipment.

The researchers plan to trial the cap - dubbed "Brainwave" - on people with severe physical disabilities to see if it can help them to control computers.

"We were able to get some results that exceeded our expectations," said Dr. Tomoyuki Sato, who led the team at Yokohama National University.

"Using this device, we intend to continue research toward the realization of a new, interface that does not rely on the five senses," he added in a statement.

The device uses an electroencephalogram (EEG) to detect electrical activity caused by changes in brainwaves.

It then uses algorithms to analyze the brainwaves and trigger a switch in a computer.

In recent decades, brain-computer interfaces have been developed which let paralysed people use robotic arms or other equipment by thinking deliberately about moving.

The new device operates on a different principle - that of "event-related potential" (ERP), a spike in brain activity that occurs when a person senses a stimulus.

In this case, the researchers used an ERP called the P300 wave. This is generated unconsciously when a person becomes aware of a stimulus - in this case, the switch being on or off.

The researchers asked 13 people to wear the Brainwave cap and try to turn on and off a virtual switch displayed on a computer screen.

Participants were asked to think "on" and "off" when a cue symbol appeared and to suppress the urge to blink.

Participants achieved an accuracy rate of 81.25% - significantly higher than the random level of 38.46%.

The researchers then tested the device on six people with severe physical disabilities caused by spinal cord injuries.

These participants achieved an accuracy rate of 63.16%, which the researchers said was "not bad" for a group that had not received any training in ERP.

The researchers plan to refine the algorithms that interpret the brainwaves and improve the Brainwave cap's performance.

The UK should give developing countries £5.5bn ($6.6bn) to fight AIDS, Gordon Brown has said.

The former prime minister made the call ahead of the G8 summit in Canada next week.

He said the "penny-pinching" of recent years had to stop if the world was to make a real impact on the disease.

And he said a comprehensive strategy was needed to tackle the virus, including affordable drugs, more prevention and a rollout of testing.

The UK has already spent £15bn on fighting the disease in the developing world. But Mr Brown said this was still not enough.

He said: "Diseases know no borders and in a world as interconnected as ours, neither can our efforts to combat them."

Mr Brown said he was encouraged by the progress that had been made in the last decade, with more than two million lives saved in Africa.

But he added: "We are now at a pivotal moment. Without greater action, AIDS could explode in the developing world.

"It is time for a comprehensive strategy on AIDS with affordable drugs, more prevention, rolling out testing and wider access to microinsurance for those who need it."

Mr Brown also warned that the world was facing a "catastrophic crisis" in relation to climate change.

And he called on the G8 to consider a tax on carbon emissions, which would force companies to take greater responsibility for the pollution they generate.

"We should be prepared to consider a tax on all forms of carbon emissions," he said.

"That would be a more effective incentive for people to reduce their carbon emissions than a voluntary approach."

Newcastle have joined the race to sign Real Madrid and Spain striker Raul Morientes, 30, who is available on a free transfer.   Owner Mike Ashley is ready to back new manager Glenn Roeder in the transfer market after the recent departure of Graeme Souness.  Morientes has been told he can leave Real Madrid this summer after falling out of favour with coach Fabio Capello.  The striker is also interesting Manchester City and Italian clubs Roma and Fiorentina.

Apple has filed a lawsuit in California against unnamed defendants it claims have leaked confidential information about its products, according to reports.

The lawsuit filed in Santa Clara county Superior Court on Saturday lists as defendants a number of unnamed people who have "unlawfully obtained and leaked Apple's confidential information," according to court documents seen by TechCrunch.

It claimed that the defendants were in possession of "sensitive confidential Apple information" including product meeting minutes, product development information, and information regarding Apple's internal procedures related to its product releases.

The lawsuit stated that the defendants were part of a conspiracy to leak Apple's confidential information in order to reap profits from short-selling Apple's stock and driving down the share price.

It claimed that the defendants had been "rewarded handsomely" for their short selling and were "repeatedly using their access to Apple's secured network to steal sensitive proprietary information."

Over the past few years, Apple has suffered a number of product leaks including some of its latest iPhones, iPads, and Macs.

The lawsuit comes a week after Apple announced that it was killing the much-rumored AirPower wireless charging pad as it "did not meet Apple's standards."

Apple declined to comment on the lawsuit.

UK Coal has posted a deeper first-half loss as it continues to suffer on weak coal prices and a strong pound.

The company, which returned to the London Stock Exchange in June, reported a loss of £43.9m ($61.8m) in the six months to 30 June, compared with a loss of £17.2m a year earlier.

The group has been hit by a number of factors, including the strong performance of the pound, weaker coal prices and "high production costs" at one of its sites.

The company has been hit by a number of factors

The strong pound has made its exports more expensive, while coal prices have struggled to recover from their recent historic lows.

The miner also cited "high production costs" at its Thoresby site, where it recently invested in a new "longwall" mining machine.

The group added that it had made a "solid start" to the second half of the year, but uncertainty in the market meant it was "not recommending any dividend for the 2018 financial year".

UK Coal was taken over by a group of investors, including its former management, in April last year.

The firm was delisted from the London Stock Exchange in October 2013 after it was hit by falling coal prices and a tough market for coal miners.

However, it returned to the stock market in June this year, floating on the London Stock Exchange's Alternative Investment Market (AIM).

As part of the float, the company raised £3.5m through a placing of shares priced at 110p each.

The group's chief executive, Jon Meeching, said the company was "pleased" with progress in the first half of the year.

"We have a solid platform from which to deliver future growth and enhance value for all our stakeholders as we go through the second half of the year and beyond," he said.

"We are experiencing a period of extreme volatility in global coal markets which is affecting commodity prices and currency exchange rates."

"Whilst we are confident that our mining operations are robust and well placed to manage these challenges, there is a degree of uncertainty as to how these will affect the group's financial performance in the short term."

"Consequently, whilst we are encouraged by the group's performance in the first half of 2018, we remain cautious in our outlook for the full year."

"The government has been accused of 'ignoring' its own advisory panel on the appointment of Britain's new top lawyer. Last week it emerged that the person the government had chosen to be the next attorney general was being considered for a peerage. silky diplomacy and polished performances in the Commons had made him the 'best person' for the post.

But the commission, which advises the government on judicial appointments, had ranked Lord Goldsmith ninth in its list of candidates. The commission's chair said that his appointment had been 'departing from the usual procedures'. The prime minister 'completely ignored' its advice, he added.

The Liberal Democrat peer Lord Carlile said that the appointment had been made through 'the back door'.

'I think there is a credible argument that this breaches the ministerial code,' he added.

The code says ministers should not just consider ability, but also the need to 'promote political balance'.

Lord Goldsmith's office has refused to comment on the appointment process.

The attorney general is the government's chief legal adviser and has frequent contact with the prime minister, cabinet and other ministers."

Caption: Egypt to sell off state-owned bank - BBC News

Subcaption: A deal to sell a majority stake in the National Bank of Egypt (NBE) has been agreed, officials say.

The bank's chairman said a number of investors would buy a 51% stake. Details of the deal are expected to be announced later on Thursday. The government is selling state firms to help reduce its debt. The sell-off comes as Egypt battles inflation - which hit 18% in November - and a slump in the value of its currency.

The deal entails the participation of a number of strategic investors, the bank's chairman, Hisham Okasha, confirmed to Reuters news agency. He did not disclose the identities of the buyers. "It's a great day for the National Bank of Egypt," he was quoted as saying. "We are selling at a good price and we are selling to strategic investors."

The bank's sale has been on the cards for years. In 2017, the Egyptian government signed a memorandum of understanding with Saudi Arabian investors, but the deal never materialised. A number of other, unsuccessful attempts to sell the bank have also been made.

The NBE is the largest of Egypt's state-owned banks. It handles about half of the nation's banking transactions. The bank's assets were about 1.7 trillion Egyptian pounds ($119bn; £95bn) at the end of 2020.

The Egyptian government has been trying to reduce its debt, which stood at 108% of GDP in the second quarter of 2021. Last year, it sold its remaining stake in the Middle East's largest container handling company, Suez Canal Container Terminal, to the Dubai-based DP World.

This year, the government started selling state-owned enterprises in sectors including pharmaceuticals, chemicals and fertilisers. Late last year, it launched a programme to sell off state-owned property. In November, it sold a landmark government-owned property in Cairo.

The sale of state firms comes as Egypt battles inflation, which hit 18% in November - its highest level in 30 years. The country's currency has also slumped from about 15 Egyptian pounds to the dollar in 2019 to about 20 pounds to the dollar now.

The Central Bank of Egypt has raised its key interest rate by 3% to curb inflation. But it has faced criticism that its attempts to control rising prices have not been enough.

New York (CNN) -- Nearly all the pilots of US Airways have agreed to a 15 percent pay cut, the airline's chief executive said Monday.

CEO Doug Parker said in a memo to employees the agreement saves about $600 million a year and puts the company "on a more viable cost structure."

The memo said that 94 percent of the pilots had agreed to the cut, and that management is working to get similar concessions from the airline's dispatchers, customer service agents, and managers.

In a statement, the Air Line Pilots Association said the pilot concession is a temporary measure, and that the union does not expect the airline to require such cuts in the future.

The union said the cuts were needed for the company's financial health, and that the pilot group was not optimistic about a recovery in air travel.

US Airways has been operating under Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection since September 2004.

Last week, Delta Air Lines asked for wage and benefit concessions from its employees, saying its costs were higher than those of its competitors.

Worldcom's former chief executive has told the BBC that he did not know about false accounting practices at the company before they were revealed in 2002.

Bernie Ebbers said he had left the company's books alone after selling its telecommunications division four years earlier.

Mr Ebbers is serving a 25-year prison sentence for his part in the $11bn (£7bn) accounting scandal.

He spoke to the BBC's Panorama as part of a documentary on the scandal, which will be aired on Monday.

Last week, former Worldcom accountant Troy Normand told Panorama that he had warned Mr Ebbers that the company was using fraudulent accounting practices to inflate its profits, but that the executive had ignored him.

"I met with Bernie Ebbers in December 2000 and I told him that I thought that the company was doing some creative accounting," he said.

"He laughed out loud and he told me that he didn't know anything about that. He said 'You know, I sell multi-million dollar businesses all the time and I've never had to doctor the books to make a sale.'"

In an exclusive interview from prison, Mr Ebbers told the BBC that Mr Normand's claims were not true.

"I had nothing to do with the accounting. I sold the operating company four years before all this happened," he said.

"The operating company had nothing to do with the accountants. I didn't deal with the accountants - I never even saw the books."

Mr Ebbers admitted that he had signed off on some of the accounting practices, but said he had not looked at them in detail or questioned them because he had trusted the people who had presented them to him.

He said he had only found out that something was wrong when Worldcom's shares crashed in 2002.

"I was stunned. I couldn't believe it," he said.

"I thought, 'How could anybody manipulate the stock market like this?' I was shocked. I was devastated."

The £24.4m ($32.5m) documentary, entitled The Fall of Worldcom, will be aired on BBC One at 2100 GMT on Monday.

British number one Kyle Edmund and Cameron Norrie have been knocked out of the Australian Open, but Dan Evans and Johanna Konta are through to the third round.

Edmund, the 2018 finalist, lost in four sets to American Sebastian Korda, and Norrie was beaten by Spanish 12th seed Pablo Carreno Busta.

But Evans fought back from a set down to beat Australia's Alex de Minaur 2-6 6-4 6-4 6-2 and reach the third round for the third time.

British number one Konta defeated Russian 17th seed Ekaterina Alexandrova 6-1 6-1 to equal her best result at Melbourne Park.

His victory meant he edged out longtime rival Jeremy Sotherton, who also finished the race just half a minute behind him.

The 34-year-old, who won gold in the 4x100m freestyle relay at London 2012, finished in a time of one hour, 50 minutes and 57 seconds.

He said he had "nothing left" towards the end of the marathon race, but added: "The crowd were just incredible."

Johnson, who also won the Dubai Marathon in 2019, finished ahead of Uganda's Abraham Kiplimo (1:51:08) and Alexander Mutiso of Kenya (1:51:36).

One of the fastest men over 10,000m and the half-marathon, Johnson only started focusing on road events in recent years.

He clocked his personal best of two hours, six minutes and 27 seconds over the marathon distance in London last year.

Halo fans are hoping for a sequel to the original game - and it could come sooner than expected.

According to the gaming news website Kotaku, multiple sources have claimed that a new Halo game will be announced at E3, a gaming event that takes place in Los Angeles from 10 to 15 June.

The report claims that the new game will be a sequel to the first Halo game, which was released in 2001. It is believed that the game will be released on Xbox 360 and will be developed by Bungie, the company that created the Halo franchise.

Bungie has yet to comment on the report.

Halo is a science fiction first-person shooter game that follows the adventures of the silent Jedi-like warrior Master Chief.

The original Halo game was followed by eight more games and has become one of the most popular video game franchises of all time. A remake of the first game - which was originally developed for the Xbox - was released for Xbox 360 in 2011.

Fans of the franchise have been waiting for a new sequel for several years. The most recent game, Halo 5, was released in 2015. 

A sequel would come at an interesting time for the franchise, as the coronavirus pandemic has led to increased demand for video games as people turn to them for entertainment while stuck at home. 

Last month, the Microsoft gaming division chief, Phil Spencer, said that the company had seen "record engagement" with Xbox during the pandemic.

Israel is looking to the United States to fill the post of governor of its central bank, according to media reports.

The job has been vacant since Stanley Fischer stepped down last month.

Media reports say Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has asked US President Donald Trump to nominate Marvin Goodfriend, a professor at Carnegie Mellon University and a former official at the Federal Reserve, for the role.

The appointment needs to be approved by the Israeli parliament.

Mr Goodfriend has not responded to the reports.

The Bank of Israel has had just seven governors since it was founded in 1954, and all have been career central bankers, rather than political appointments, according to Reuters.

The post is regarded as one of the most important in the country's economic leadership.

The bank's responsibilities include conducting monetary policy, regulating banks and financial institutions, and overseeing payments systems.

Shanxi province's banking regulator has ordered the Bank of China's branch in the provincial capital Taiyuan to suspend operations for a month after 5.13 billion yuan ($774m) went missing.

The branch's executive director, Wang Suqing, and chief accountant, Yang Jinhua, have been detained.

In a statement, the bank said it had requested the police "to promptly investigate and handle" the issue.

It said the amount involved was "relatively small" for the bank, and that it would "actively cooperate... to protect the rights and interests of customers".

The suspension order, issued on Sunday, said that the bank had made "false reports" on its financial position.

The Bank of China is the country's largest bank by assets. It is majority owned by the Chinese government.

It has 14.4 million retail customers and more than 460,000 corporate clients in Shanxi, a northern province known for its coal-mining industry.

Tom Hanks has braved the wintry weather in New York to promote his latest film A Man Called Otto.

The 68-year-old actor - who has had ticker issues in the past - smiled and waved to fans as he arrived at the premiere in Central Park.

He was joined by his wife Rita Wilson, who wrapped her arms around him to keep him warm.

A Man Called Otto is a reworking of the Swedish film A Man Called Ove, based on the novel by Fredrik Backman.

It tells the story of Otto Anderson, a grump who's given a new lease of life after a lively young family moves in next door.

Hanks said he immediately fell in love with the story when his wife Wilson - who's of Swedish descent - sent it to him.

He told the PA news agency it was a "terrific" book and he found the role "fascinating".

"It's got tremendous emotion," he said. "It's very humorous but it's got a tremendous heart to it and it allows me to behave badly, which I always appreciate.

"It's got a lot of heart and a lot of emotion and every single isolated incident in the story informs the next.

"There's a cascade of emotional events and finally there's a paying off of all of those incidents and I just loved that when I read it."

But Hanks said while he'd "love" to work with director Marc Forster again, he's not sure he's got any more "Otto" in him.

"I've played a guy who's kinda annoyed by the circumstances of his life and upset with the people around him, and that's kinda it for now," he said.

"We'll see what else happens but I gotta tell you, I can't imagine it."

A Man Called Otto opens in the US on Friday. Its UK release date is still to be confirmed.

The economy is "stronger than forecast" and GDP is growing faster than expected, as businesses invested in stockpiling ahead of the Brexit deadline, an official survey has shown.

The "flash" estimate from the Office for National Statistics (ONS) showed that in the three months to December, gross domestic product (GDP) increased by 1.3% compared with the same period a year earlier.

That was much higher than the consensus among economists of 0.4%, and ahead of the Bank of England's prediction of 1.2%.

It meant that the economy avoided a technical recession, which is two consecutive three-month periods of negative growth.

In the three months to November, GDP fell by a revised 0.2% - a slight improvement on the first estimate of a 0.3% fall.

The UK government has pledged £1bn ($1.4bn) to the international effort to develop a vaccine for coronavirus.

The sum - for research and development - will be paid in UK aid, Chancellor Rishi Sunak announced in his budget on Wednesday.

Mr Sunak said the money would help "create a vaccine" for Covid-19 "that will ensure we can protect people here in the UK and around the world".

UK aid, the Department for International Development (DfID), will also provide £388m to help end the pandemic and distribute treatments and vaccines.

It will spend £300m on the Coalition for Epidemic Preparedness Innovations (Cepi), a global alliance working on Covid-19 vaccines.

Cepi has already funded three promising candidates, according to Mr Sunak.

Additionally, DfID will give £38m to the WHO to help distribute coronavirus vaccines, treatments and tests.

It will also spend £62m on research and development, including testing new treatments.

The budget also included £1.35bn to accelerate the rollout of coronavirus vaccines, including helping the NHS to become ready to distribute a vaccine next month.

This included £150m to fund 50 million doses of a vaccine, if one becomes available, Mr Sunak said.

The budget also pledged £5bn for testing and tracing over the next six months.

Open source leaders slam patents

Patents on software are a "blight" which damage developers and businesses, leaders of some of the biggest open source software projects have said.

Patents were a "roadblock" to business and innovation, said Josh Pigford, founder of CouchDB.

And Ubuntu founder Mark Shuttleworth said software patents were "terrible" for developers.

Their comments came at the O'Reilly Open Source Convention in California.

Open source software is free and shared, so that others may help develop it.

It is usually protected by a licence which allows developers to access the source code - the instructions making up the software - so they can modify and customise it as they want.

But some software - such as Microsoft Windows and Apple's OS X - is protected by patents, meaning that the source code is a trade secret, and only the company that makes the software can see it.

This is meant to protect the investment that a company makes in its software, and prevents others from copying it.

But speaking at the O'Reilly conference, Mr Pigford said that software patents were a "blight on our industry".

"As a small technology business, you have to worry about patents on a daily basis," he said.

"When you are innovating, the last thing you want to do is to take a patent lawyer along to make sure you are not treading on someone else's toes.

"It is a huge roadblock to innovation."

Mr Shuttleworth, best known for the Ubuntu Linux distribution, said software patents were "terrible" for developers.

"As a developer, you shouldn't have to worry about the legal system when you are developing software," he said.

"Patents are incredibly expensive to get, and expensively to enforce. It is a mechanism by which lawyers get rich, at the expense of innovation."

But intellectual property lawyer Leslie Holmes said that patents were a legitimate way for companies to protect their software.

"There is a lot of misinformation about patents swirling around the computer world," she said.

"Patents are property rights, and as such they allow people to make investments in innovation knowing that they will get a return on their investment.

"You can't ignore the fact that software patents exist - they are the law of the land."

US charity anthem 'We Are The World' is re-released with some of the original artists and some new stars.

The single, re-recorded by a group of US artists to help raise money for the Haiti earthquake appeal, has entered the US singles chart at number two.

The song has raised $300,000 (£200,000) for the We Are The World Foundation, set up after the original was released in 1985 to help African famine relief.

Organizers hope that this year's version will raise $1 million in the next few months.

The song was originally recorded by a group of 45 artists including Michael Jackson, Cyndi Lauper, Bruce Springsteen and Madonna.

This year's line-up comprises of both original singers and new stars, including Jennifer Hudson, Miley Cyrus, and Justin Bieber.

The project was the idea of producer Randy Phillips, who wanted to re-record the song in order to raise money for the victims of the Haiti earthquake.

He said he wanted to "continue the legacy" of the original song and to "encourage today's generation to stand up and take action".

The song was made available for download on iTunes and other digital music services on 14 February.

The proceeds from the sales of the single will go to the We Are The World Foundation.

The number of people with broadband will double by 2010, from 400 million to 800 million, according to a study by US market research company, Forrester.

The study also found that the number of PCs in the same markets will grow from 650 million to 1.2 billion.

"Computer ownership increasingly goes hand-in-hand with high-speed internet connections," said Forrester senior analyst, Johan Hovold.

"As a result, the number of PCs in mature markets will grow only slightly, while PC ownership in developing markets will more than triple," he added.

Forrester based its findings on analysis of computer and broadband penetration in 22 developed and developing countries, including the US, UK, Germany, Japan, China and India.

The research focused on what it called the "wired countries" - those with the infrastructure to deliver high-speed internet connections to homes.

At present there are 400 million such connections, but Forrester said this would increase to between 800 million and one billion by 2010.

While the number of PCs in "wired" countries would grow by about 17% in the next seven years, reaching 670 million, the research group expects PC ownership in developing countries to more than triple from 170 million to 510 million.

ABBA singer Agnetha Faltskog has entered the Sunday Times music rich list for the first time, thanks to the success of the band's songs decades after they split up.

The Swedish pop icons have raised £142m in the past year, with their albums and hits streamed more than 430m times.

It is the first time 68-year-old Faltskog, 70-year-old Anni-Frid Lyngstad, 75-year-old Benny Andersson and 74-year-old Björn Ulvaeus have appeared on the UK-based list together.

This year's Sunday Times Rich List measured fortunes from 24 April 2021 to 23 April 2022.

Abba gold
Abba - short for Agnetha, Björn, Benny and Anni-Frid - were among the most successful acts of the 1970s, with a string of hits including Waterloo, Dancing Queen and Knowing Me, Knowing You.

The group split up in 1982, but resumed touring in 2016 - shortly after the release of the hit musical Mamma Mia! - and have not looked back.

Abba Voyage, a staged concert, opened in London last May and will visit nine UK cities during its initial run.

Ulvaeus said in a statement: "Tracking the success of Abba's songs is a bit like tracking the stock market.

"You know you have had a good year when your global sales have hit the jackpot and that was the case last year."

He added the group had achieved their success "without belonging to any major label", referring to the band's independent operation.

 Myth busting
The Abba story is among the most myth-busting in pop, according to Hodgson.

"They are not a one-hit wonder - they had 20 international hits. People think Abba is a young person's obsession but, actually, it transcends generations," he said.

Hodgson points out that while other bands have split up, Abba have always remained active - and that their break enabled them to reflect their true value.

"Had they carried on making records in the early 1980s, they would be a really good rock act but no-one would be saying, 'Abba are worth £500m'."

UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson is "uncertain" if he will compete in the 2028 Los Angeles Olympics, according to sources.

Johnson, a keen athlete and former captain of his Oxford University rugby union team, has in the past hinted he would like to become the first serving British prime minister to compete in the Olympics.

But sources close to him have told the BBC the 56-year-old is now not sure if he will be selected for Great Britain's rowing squad for the LA Games.

In April 2020, when the UK was entering its first lockdown, Johnson said he perhaps exerted himself too much in training.

"I probably overdid it," he said at the time. "I think that's how I ended up in hospital sweating away like a bull."

After he was discharged from hospital, Johnson confirmed he had resigned as captain of his local north London rowing club,rc Racer.

In 2018, he rowed with London 2012 gold medallist William Lockwood, also from his local club, and UK Sport chef de mission Mark England, among others, in a charity race at the Henley Royal Regatta.

The prime minister's office has been contacted for comment.

Last month, it was confirmed the prime minister had received hospital treatment for "persistent" symptoms of coronavirus, nine days after testing positive for the virus.

Johnson, who spent three nights in intensive care, returned to work last Tuesday but said he was "not yet ready" to end his period of self-isolation.

In late March, the prime minister announced he had tested positive for coronavirus, saying he had experienced "symptoms" including a high temperature and a cough.

The X Factor is to return for a second series on BBC Three.

The singing talent show debuted on the channel last year and averaged more than half a million viewers per episode.

Host Olly Murs, who won the first series as a contestant in 2009, said he was "very excited" about the new series.

"We're looking for singers with charisma, personality and, of course, star quality," he said.

The show will return to BBC Three in the summer with a week of auditions before moving to BBC One for the semi-finals and the final. 

Last year 220,000 people applied to take part. 

Simon Cowell, who originally launched The X Factor on ITV in 2004, said: "I'm thrilled BBC Three have asked us to return.

"Working with the BBC is exciting, there is a lot of important stuff we have planned for 2022 and I'm grateful they're letting us do it."

The IMF has agreed to give Turkey a fresh loan of more than $3bn to support the country's economy.

The announcement came at the end of a visit to Ankara by the IMF's managing director, Kristalina Georgieva.

She said the $3.6bn (£2.8bn) loan would be subject to regular reviews "to ensure it remains tailored to Turkey's needs".

The lira has lost more than 40% of its value since the start of the year.

Ms Georgieva said the IMF was "pleased to support Turkey's ambitious and decisive policy agenda".

The loan agreement comes after Turkey's finance minister announced a new economic programme to revive the struggling economy.

The reforms include reducing the government's expenditure and current account deficit, boosting exports and increasing the country's revenue.

However, the Turkish lira fell 5% against the dollar after the loan was announced, before recovering its losses.

The currency has been hit by the Turkish government's attempts to reduce inflation, which stands at around 20%, by raising interest rates.

But analysts say the rate hikes are not enough to tackle the country's inflation problem.

As part of the agreement, the IMF said the loan would be accompanied by "strong conditionality" and that it had already received "strong commitments" from the Turkish government.

It said the funding was designed to support the authorities' "ambitious and decisive" policy agenda and promote sustainable economic growth.

Bas Lansdorp is the pioneer of a game-changing aircraft which has propelled us into a new age of sustainable aviation, and yet his work has not been recognised by the Academy. Is the film industry, like the aviation industry, going to take a while longer to leave no fossil behind? 

This seems to be the case – especially when it comes to telling the stories of pioneering visionaries in the field of sustainable technology. The UK's highest-paid broadcaster has attacked the government's "pay later" budget, saying it would not help those most in need.

Speaking on the BBC's Andrew Marr show, the presenter Andrew Neil said the measures in the budget were "balancing the books in five years' time" and amounted to "giving voters a choice between a tax rise or a spending cut".

He added that the autumn statement was "an absolutely clear signal that the age of largesse is over".

His comments came as Chancellor Jeremy Hunt announced a squeeze on spending and a hike in taxes for millions of people.

Mr Hunt said he had made "difficult decisions" in order to restore confidence after the economic crisis caused by the pandemic and the war in Ukraine.

The decision by ministers to factor in A-level results when calculating university fees has been criticised by the head of England's colleges.

Bill Watkin, chief executive of the Sixth Form Colleges Association (SFCA), said the "distortion" in the system risked hitting students aiming to go to university after studying A-levels at a school or college.

HONG KONG (Reuters) - Asian markets dropped on Thursday as a earthquake shook Japan, with the broader region's investors also keeping a wary eye on developments in Ukraine and weighing the prospect of higher U.S. interest rates.

The Nikkei 225 index in Japan, the first market to react following the quake, closed 1.4% lower.

The MSCI's broadest index of Asia-Pacific shares outside Japan (.MIAPJ0000PUS) fell 1.1%, pulling back from a four-month high touched in the previous session.

Thursday's downturn came as U.S. Fed officials were out in force with four more policymakers saying they were ready to raise rates at their meeting next week should jobs data due later in the day show workers are gaining ground.

The comment by Atlanta Fed President Raphael Bostic was the most explicit signal from a Fed official that rates would rise next week, and intensified fears the central bank was getting closer to starting a prolonged cycle of rate hikes. 

“Expectations of a more aggressive Fed sent a jolt through markets,” said Steen Jakobsen, chief economist at Saxo Bank. “The topic of inflation is back with a bang.”

The EU parliament's legal affairs committee has voted to scrap software patent law from the bloc's upcoming AI regulations.

The committee adopted a report on the AI Act that excluded software patents from its scope.

The report said that excluding software from patentability was "necessary to promote innovation".

And it warned that software patents presented a "risk of ever-greening" - a reference to the practice of extending patent protection indefinitely.

Abbott Laboratories, IBM, Microsoft and Samsung were among those campaigning for software to be included in the AI Act. 

They argued that a patent system would encourage innovation and stop AI technology being locked in a legal battle over who had the rights to it.

But activists said that software patents were a threat to freedom of speech and data security.

And digital rights group EDRi said that the inclusion of software patents in the AI Act would have created a "new digital lockdown".

"[It] would make software patents stronger and give patent trolls more tools to exploit small developers and innovators", it said.

The EU parliament's vote is not the final say on the matter.

Other EU institutions - the European Commission and council of ministers - will now consider the report drawn up by the parliament. 

The AI Act is on a slower track than other EU legislation, with an expected adoption date in 2025.

Reading, writing and arithmetic have been joined by a modern version of Pyramus and Thisbe's lip-reading love affair in the bedroom - the couple who communicate by texting on their MP3 players.

The humble MP3 player has been enlisted into almost every area of life - jogging, cooking, even religion - in the way that its predecessor the Walkman was adopted by the 1980s yuppie.

This week's Gadget Show, broadcast on Channel 5, demonstrated how MP3 technology is becoming increasingly interwoven into everyday life in Britain.

The programme featured a couple who have adapted their MP3 players to convert text into speech, so they can send messages to each other from their bedrooms.

Police in Norfolk have joined forces with local councils to fight anti-social behaviour by issuing youths with GPS-enabled MP3 players.

The devices, which look like ordinary MP3 players, can send a signal to the police and local councils if the wearer enters a restricted area.

 Sellers of more conventional MP3 players have reported a surge in sales ahead of Christmas, with middle-aged professionals leading the way.

Currys chief executive Andrew Higginson said that sales of MP3 players had exceeded the company's expectations.

"They are becoming mainstream," he said. "We are seeing them appeal to a much broader group than the traditional young tech-savvy consumer."

The most popular models are those with screens, which allow users to watch videos as well as listen to music.

"Once you've got a screen, you can do lots more things. The sky's the limit as far as functionality is concerned," said Mr Higginson.

Online electrical retailer ao.com reported that sales of MP3 players with video capability had risen by 300% so far this year.

The managing director, Andy Haylor, said that the most popular brand was Apple's iPod, with the video iPod leading the way.

"The larger capacity the better, because you can store more music and video content," he said. "We're also seeing the rise of the digital radio, with more and more consumers looking to tune in to digital radio, in the car and at home."

But the Gadget Show found that the MP3 revolution has also split the generations.

Younger members of the same family were seen struggling to understand why their parents and grandparents were so fascinated by the devices.

The election has been dominated by grievances over public services, unemployment, and corruption.

Sunday's vote is the fifth since the US-led invasion of 2003 that toppled Saddam Hussein and ushered in an era of deep instability and political strife. 

For the first time since the US-led invasion in 2003, no foreign forces were present during the election.

The latest round of talks on Russia's accession to the WTO has made progress, with negotiators finalizing several key issues, including Russia's commitment to limit agricultural subsidies and to open its markets to imports of meat and dairy products. 
Other issues that remained unresolved included the country's approach to intellectual property rights, with the US in particular concerned about Russia's implementation of WTO rules in this area. 
Nevertheless, both sides expressed satisfaction with the outcome of the talks, and Russia's accession to the WTO is now expected to be completed in the near future, subject to the approval of the organization's members.

Sales of television sets have stalled in the UK as broadband availability improves, according to a recent study by regulator Ofcom.

Sales of TVs have fallen by 8% since 2019, Ofcom said, whilst the number of households with broadband increased by 7%.

The study did not provide a reason for the correlation, but it comes as households spend more time online.

Ofcom said that homes now have more devices capable of connecting to the internet than people, with each person owning on average 3.6 devices, up from 3.3 in 2019.

The study also found that nearly all households had internet access, with only 3% of households without it. This has increased by 1.2 million from 2019.

Ofcom said that the increase could be explained by the fact that most households who wanted broadband and were able to get it, now have it.

However, it also showed that there were still areas where broadband was difficult to get, with some people struggling to get a decent connection.

The study also found that streaming services such as Netflix and Amazon Prime were increasingly popular, with most households now having at least one such service.

The former Manchester United manager is reportedly under consideration for a role at the club he enjoyed so much success with between 2004 and 2008. Mourinho has been out of work since being sacked by United in December 2018, but it is understood that he would be willing to listen to any offers for a return to Stamford Bridge.

His agent, Jorge Mendes, has a close relationship with the Chelsea owners and it is understood that he would be interested in a return to England.

Mourinho delivered the Premier League title and three League Cups during his first spell in London and Chelsea officials believe he could be the perfect candidate to deliver immediate success.

Clicking on the first link when you search for something on the web is probably not the best way to find what you're looking for. That's because it's not always a genuine search result. Instead, it could be an ad paid for by companies to make sure their service stands out.

These ads look just like regular search results. They often appear at the top of the page and are highlighted in yellow. And they come with a "Sponsored" label.

But a survey has found that many people still can't spot the difference.

The BBC spoke to Caroline Wilson, from Milton Keynes, who searched for a well-known government portal. She was surprised to find herself on a clone site which charged a fee. "It was a redirect," she says. "I was actually shocked, because I never expected that. I thought I'd clicked on the actual Government website." 

Ms Wilson says she didn't notice the word "ad" written in small letters next to the link.

"If I had been looking more carefully, I would have noticed that. But I wasn't," she says. "It was very subtle." 

 Researchers at Cisco Systems carried out a survey to find out just how good at spotting these ads people are. They created several search terms linked to financial products, and used an iPhone, laptop and Android phone to conduct the searches.

Overall, the researchers stumbled upon dozens of clone sites. In some cases, these charged a fee or got users to fill in forms with personal details.

Among the search terms they used were "taxi insurance", "life insurance" and "government gateway". They also searched for well-known brands, including M&S and Sainsbury's. In each case, the genuine websites appeared further down the page.

The researchers concluded that the average person would struggle to spot ads. In a worst-case scenario, this could result in someone paying money needlessly, or exposing their personal details.

Aid agencies have insisted that Thursday's tsunami in the Pacific will not divert attention or resources from the humanitarian crisis in Africa. The 8.9-magnitude earthquake and subsequent tsunami, which struck south-east Asia, have killed thousands of people and left many more missing. Aid agencies have launched appeals for funds to deal with the twin disasters. (£) This comes as Africa is battling its worst drought in four decades, which has left at least 11 million people facing famine in Kenya, Ethiopia and Somalia. The UN has appealed for $2.5bn to help more than 16 million people in the region. Mary Creagh, the shadow international development secretary, has urged British ministers to "take a lead" in providing aid for the African famine. "The government must not allow the international focus on the Pacific earthquake and tsunami to distract from this horror," she said. At least 2,000 people have died and thousands are missing after the wave struck countries including Indonesia, Thailand and Sri Lanka.

The current system is ‘barrier after barrier’, one A-list actress says, as women and their reps prepare for Oscar season with discussions of ‘gender injustice’ 
The systemic injustice affecting Hollywood’s top female talent is clearly illustrated in a new report showing it could take decades for them to earn what their male counterparts take home in a year.

The study, based on data from Forbes’s annual lists of the world’s highest-paid actors and actresses since 2010, found that despite an increase in feminist discourse in Hollywood, the pay gap is actually getting wider.

Meanwhile, interviews with 30 agents, managers and lawyers who represent some of the industry’s biggest stars reveal a complex web of discriminatory practices that allow men to continue to earn exponentially more than women.

The study, conducted by the Institute for Research on Labor and Employment at the University of California, Berkeley, found that in the past 12 years, the top 10 actresses earned a combined $3.3bn, or $30m per actress on average.

In contrast, the top 10 actors earned a combined $7.1bn, or $70m per actor on average – dwarfing their female counterparts’ earnings.

This means it would take the top-earning actress, Emma Stone, almost three decades to earn what the top-earning actor, Dwayne Johnson, made in one.

Bayer, the parent company of Monsanto, has been fined $1.5bn for bribery in Russia.

The German chemicals giant was charged with funneling cash to a foundation run by Russian intelligence services, with the aim of winning favour for Monsanto in the country.

The Kremlin said it was "ready to cooperate" with the German authorities in their investigation.

The Berlin prosecutor's office said Bayer had "made inaccurate statements" when it acquired Monsanto in 2018 and had "failed to comply with its obligations under the German foreign trade law".

The company said it would "vigorously defend itself against these allegations".

"There is no evidence that the payments in question led to an illegal benefit," it added in a statement.

The German authorities said the payments had been made between 2005 and 2013.

They said some of the cash had been donated to a foundation run by Russia's main intelligence service, the FSB, and later used for "political purposes".

TASS news agency reported that the funds were used to pay for equipment and infrastructure at a children's hospital in the city of Omsk.

The fine comes two years after Bayer bought Monsanto for $63bn, and is one of the biggest anti-corruption penalties ever imposed by German authorities.

The company has already faced massive lawsuits in the US over its Roundup weedkiller, which has been linked to cancer.

In a statement, Bayer said the fine would not affect its full-year outlook, and that it would not affect the sale of Monsanto products in Russia.

Chelsea have beaten Arsenal 3-1 in the final of the FA Cup to clinch the first major trophy of the Roman Abramovich era. 

The match at Wembley was goalless at half-time but turned into a thriller after Blues striker Eddie Newton scored early in the second period. 

The Gunners equalised through a rare goal from defender Steve Bould before second-half substitute Gus Poyet hit the winner with a spectacular strike from 35 yards. 

It was Chelsea's first FA Cup final triumph for twenty-two years and came just three days after the club had secured a place in next season's Champions League by finishing fourth in the Premiership.

The UK should commit to a joint aid programme with the US and other G7 countries to fund global education, stop HIV and wipe out malaria, Gordon Brown has said.

The former UK prime minister said it was time for Britain to return to the forefront of international efforts to eradicate preventable diseases.

In a speech to the Centre for Global Development in Washington, he will call for a £5.5bn fund to tackle Aids, tuberculosis and malaria.

Mr Brown said that it was the "height of hypocrisy" for any government to talk about national security while failing to tackle diseases.

The fund would be used to target illnesses which have made a comeback due to coronavirus lockdowns and disruptions to health services around the world, according to the proposed plan.

It would include £1.7bn for a national plan to end Aids by 2030, £1.2bn for a global fund to fight tuberculosis, and £2bn for the elimination of malaria.

England striker, Harry Kane, has welcomed the decision by the Football Association to fine former England captain, Gareth Southgate, for his involvement in a row during a quiz night in Sussex. Southgate had been accused of being rude to a quiz host, who Southgate claimed was biased against his team. The FA decided to fine Southgate for his behavior, and he has accepted the sanction. 

Kane, who replaced Southgate as England captain following the quiz night, stated, "I think it's a good thing. Obviously, looking back on it now, it's not something that should have happened."

England's manager, Gareth Southgate, also commented on the incident, stating, "I accept that I should have handled the situation differently, and I have learned from it. I do want to clarify that at no point did I or any of my teammates make a malicious or discriminatory comment. This was an important lesson for me and one that I have learned from."

The incident has been a source of controversy in the media, with some people arguing that the FA's decision was too harsh, while others believe that it was necessary to sanction Southgate in order to set a precedent.

Norwegian arbitrator Odd Arnesen has denied reports that he has fallen out with International Olympic Committee (IOC) president Thomas Bach over the handling of the Russian doping scandal. Last week Arnesen, who is chair of the IOC's coordination commission for the 2024 Paris Olympics, suggested that Bach was putting his own reputation first ahead of clean sport when he blocked International Weightlifting Federation (IWF) president Tamas Ajan from attending the Olympic Summit in Lausanne. "I think he (Bach) is concerned about his own image and reputation," Arnesen told Norwegian broadcaster NRK. "It would have been better if he had expressed that he cared about clean sport. "But he's worried about how this looks, and especially how it appears in Russia." However, in a statement sent to NRK on Sunday, Arnesen said he "never stated or indicated" that Bach was "concerned about his own image and reputation". "I do not question the integrity of President Bach," the statement added.

Music megastar Jay-Z has announced that he is launching his own record label, bringing together a roster of diverse artists. The label, called "Roc Nation Records", an extension of Jay's existing Roc Nation entertainment company, aims to provide artists with a platform to be heard and to build their careers. 

The label's roster already includes a wide range of artists, from rising stars to established acts, including Rihanna, Kanye West, J. Cole, and British singer Rita Ora. Roc Nation Records will be an exclusive license partner with Universal Music Group distribution. 

Jay-Z, who has won 21 Grammy Awards and sold over 75 million albums, assures that he will not be involved in the day-to-day operations of the label, instead, he plans to focus on the creative side and leave the business side to experienced executives. He will also serve as the chairman of the company. 

Roc Nation Records will prioritize artist development and will provide a range of services to its artists, including marketing, promotion, and tour support. 

The launch of Roc Nation Records is a significant development in the music industry, as it marks the latest attempt by a major artist to take control of their career and to challenge the traditional record label model. It remains to be seen whether Roc Nation Records will be a success, but with Jay-Z's reputation and experience in the music industry, it has the potential to make a major impact.

Britain's Tim Henman finally won his battle with rival Greg Rusedski as he reached the quarter-finals of the Nasdaq-100 Open in Miami.
The Briton has lost the last six times they have met, including two five-set matches at Grand Slam events.
But Henman earned a straight-set victory 6-3 7-6 against the Canadian in Florida.
And the 30-year-old admitted his relief at finally getting one over on his friend of 15 years.
"It's been a long time coming, I'm very happy," said the world number 48, who faces Russia's Marat Safin next.
"To beat Greg you have to play very solid and take your chances when they come along and I was able to do that today."

Rusedski, ranked nine places higher than his rival at 29 in the world, made a confident start to the match but could not maintain his early advantage.
And Henman, who has never beaten his rival on a hard court, took full advantage to win in one hour and 42 minutes.

"I played well today," added Henman. "I executed my game plan well and played smart tennis.
"I stuck to my guns and played aggressively when I had the opportunity. I served well and came up with some big first serves at the right time."

The win took Henman into his first quarter-final of 2004 and his first since August 2002.
And the triumph was all the more sweet given it came against a player who has had the better of him for so long.

"It's nice to get a win against Greg," added Henman. "We've known each other for 15 years, we're good friends and it's special to beat him.
"I know what he's capable of and I know how dangerous he is but today it went my way."

In a stunning comeback, former world no. 1 Roger Federer suffered a quarter-final defeat at the hands of Andy Murray in five sets at the Swiss Indoors in Basel on Thursday.

The creator of Spider-Man, Stan Lee, has won a civil lawsuit against his former business managers who were accused of mishandling his fortune and allegedly “plundering” his wealth.

Los Angeles Superior Court Judge Michelle Williams Croft ruled on Tuesday that former executives at Lee’s company, POW! Entertainment, and its related entities had breached their fiduciary duties to the comic book legend.

“Stan Lee secured the rights to his own name, and those related to his intellectual property,” Judge Croft said, according to the Hollywood Reporter.

“It is ironic that Stan Lee, the man who created characters who fought against injustice, succumbed to injustice,” the judge added.

The case centered on whether POW! executives had the right to sell Lee’s name for use in entertainment and merchandise.

Lee’s lawyers argued that POW! executives sold his name without his consent to an company called RHINO Group, which sought to license Lee’s name to a range of products from cereals to electronics.

His attorneys said that RHINO paid $100,000 (£82,000) to POW! and $1m to Lee’s daughter for the rights to use the Lee name.

Lee’s lawyers also claimed that the executives had not given him any accounting of the money they had earned on his behalf.

They further alleged that the company had paid Lee “only a small fraction” of the millions it earned from the Spider-Man and Marvel Comics creator’s work.

Lee’s attorneys argued that their client had been cheated out of millions in revenue from the sales of his work and sought damages in excess of $1bn.

In a statement, Lee’s attorney, Jonathan Freidin, said: “Mr Lee and the Stan Lee Family are thrilled with the court’s decision, which confirms their long-standing belief that Stan was cheated out of billions of dollars by companies that he owned.”

POW! and its related entities, and RHINO, have made no public statement on the ruling.

Lee, who died in 2018 at the age of 95, is also known for creating Marvel Comics characters including Iron Man, The Hulk and the X-Men.

The number of people in the US who are employed or looking for work rose unexpectedly in September, official data shows. The labour market was expected to weaken after a burst of hiring in August as coronavirus cases surged, but data from the Bureau of Labor Statistics (BLS) showed further gains in the unemployment rate. The rate rose to 4.8% in September from 4.5% in August, according to the BLS data released on Wednesday. Meanwhile, the number of non-farm payrolls increased by 194,000 in September, beating estimates of about 155,000. 

In the report, BLS noted that there was a decline in government jobs last month, with state and local education seeing job losses. But the worst of the layoffs appeared to be over, as most school districts have started the new academic year and hired staff. The report also showed that the number of jobs in the food services and drinking industry declined, as well as in the arts, entertainment, and recreation industry. 

The report was released as Federal Reserve officials concluded their latest two-day policy meeting. The central bank said it would soon start reducing its monthly bond purchases, but held off on raising interest rates, saying it was still assessing the impact of the Covid-19 pandemic on the labour market. 

The yield on the 10-year US Treasury note rose following the jobs data release, reaching 1.6% ahead of the Fed's decision.

The battle to keep the European Union's deficit within the limits of the community budget appeared to be over last night with the announcement of a new truce. 

Governments had been struggling to meet the rules of the Growth and Stability Pact, aimed at keeping the lid on spending and ensuring sound public finances.

The pact permitted a deficit of 3% of national income, but many countries were well above that. 

The old rules required a 0.5% surplus by 2025, but the new rules allow for a deficit of up to 3% until 2024, and 2.8% the year after. 

Countries that have repeatedly breached the deficit limit, such as Belgium, Spain and Portugal, now have more room to manoeuvre. 

The easing comes as inflation is soaring and several EU countries, including Germany, the bloc's largest economy, are now in recession.

Professor John Hills, director of pensions at the Institute for Fiscal Studies (IFS), said that while he did not think the current system was fair, there were other ways in which people could save money.
