Prof Hills also called on the government to introduce a new way of calculating the amount of tax paid by each individual.

In his speech, Prof Hills said: "I don't think we are doing enough to make sure that people have enough to live on and I do think that the state pension is a disgrace."

'Unfair'

But he added: "There are some things you can do about it. You can increase the age of eligibility for the state pension so that people who are older get more than they would otherwise get.

"You can change the way you calculate your tax bill so that people who earn less pay more tax than they might otherwise pay.

"And you can look at how you measure what you're paying for and say 'well, if we just take into account the value of the goods and services that people buy then we'll be able to give them a better deal'."

A British computer pioneer has been found to have made an astonishing discovery – that he was born in 1882, not 1888 as previously thought.

Sir Clive Sinclair, who died last year aged 90, had always claimed his birth certificate showed him as being born on 1 January 1882 but now it seems he may have been mistaken.

His family said they were shocked when they discovered the error and are considering legal action against the government for compensation.

Sir Clive's great-grandson, David Sinclair, told BBC Radio 4's Today programme: "We're going through all our paperwork and we've got some documents which show that Sir Clive was actually born on 1 January 1882."

He added: "It's quite extraordinary really because he'd never mentioned anything about this before. He just assumed that he was born in 1888."

Mr Sinclair said the family had been trying to find out more about their ancestor since his death in 2011.

They believe there could be other errors with Sir Clive's birth certificate and are looking into whether any of them can be corrected.

In a statement released by the Department for Work and Pensions (DWP), officials said: "There is no evidence to suggest that Sir Clive Sinclair ever changed his name or date of birth.

"However, if you have any information about your own birth records please contact us so we can investigate further."

A new plan calling on the government to pay for a massive injection of cash into social care, including tens of billions extra over four years, was given its best chance on Wednesday when former health secretary Andrew Lansley unveiled his proposal before an audience of senior Tory MPs who had demanded he put down his pencil and follow up. The draft document which will form part of the coalition's forthcoming autumn statement will see the introduction of universal access to community medical centres (CMCs), as well as free personalised prescriptions at GPs' surgeries. In other moves, those aged 60 and above would be able to opt out of paying GP prescription charges from 2014. And the current system of funding care – provided by local councils based around clinical need rather than demand – could change under the proposals. A detailed set of recommendations on how to make life easier for people with limited or no money to buy medicines for themselves were presented in an 11-page white paper. Mr Lansley's group is considering including measures that will help hard-pressed patients, such as ensuring they get subsidised prescriptions so they can continue taking their medication without fear of a bill for it. Other areas being looked at include the creation of dedicated beds for children and disabled adults, free eye tests to prevent blindness, the provision of community care resources and information services and increased income tax concessions for some parts of society, such as older people. One Tory MP said Mr Lansley should have introduced the ideas sooner, but they wanted details about what sort of extra investment might ultimately fall across. He praised one proposed idea - called the Personal Healthcare Tax Offset (PHOTO) which will encourage households with incomes below £10,420 per year to purchase private medicine and use a special discount rate when picking it up. It has been floated by Liberal Democrat Vince Cable a month ago. But David Willetts yesterday rejected suggestions of such schemes and insisted there is plenty more to come next year. The UK's most senior judge has clashed with ministers over the government's plans to scrap the Human Rights Act.

Lord Neuberger said the act had "done a great deal of good" and it would be "a great pity" to get rid of it.

But Justice Secretary Michael Gove said the act had been "misused" and was not compatible with British values.

The government has said it will replace the act with a British Bill of Rights.

The Human Rights Act, introduced in 1998, incorporates the European Convention on Human Rights into UK law.

It means individuals can take cases to the UK courts if they believe their human rights have been breached, rather than having to go to the European Court of Human Rights in Strasbourg.

'Pity to scrap it'

Speaking at an event in London, Lord Neuberger said the act had been "on the whole... very successful".

"It would be a great pity to scrap it," he said.

"I think it has done a great deal of good, not just in this country but also in other countries which have looked at our experience."

Lord Neuberger, who is due to retire as president of the Supreme Court next year, also said the act had been "good for democracy" as it had helped to ensure parliamentarians were aware of human rights issues.

But he added that the act was "not perfect" and there were "one or two areas where it could be improved".

'Misused'

In response, Mr Gove said the act had been "misused" by judges and had led to a "worrying" expansion of the role of the judiciary.

He said the act had been "used to re-write legislation" and had been interpreted in a way that was "not compatible with British values".

"The Human Rights Act has led to a situation where judges feel that it is their role to take a political decision which should properly be made by elected representatives," he said.

"That is not compatible with the rule of law."

Mr Gove said the government's plans for a British Bill of Rights would "restore the proper balance" between the judiciary and parliament.

The government has said it will consult on the plans later this year.

Officials in Europe have blamed the US for the dollar's fall to record lows against the euro.

European Central Bank head Jean-Claude Trichet said the weak dollar was a "serious concern" and called on the US to take steps to repair its economy.

His comments came a day after EU finance ministers urged the US to take action to stem the dollar's decline.

The dollar has tumbled against the euro and other major currencies in recent months as investors bet on US economic weakness.

On Thursday, the euro hit a new high of $1.5910 - its strongest level since it was introduced in 1999.

The dollar also hit new lows against the Japanese yen and the Swiss franc.

'No winner'

Mr Trichet said the sharp fall in the dollar - which has lost about 15% of its value against the euro in the past six months - was a worry for Europe.

"Obviously, we are very concerned about the situation," he told a news conference in Frankfurt.

"It's a very serious concern because we think that, in the current situation, there is no winner in a currency war," he said.

"Everybody loses in a currency war."

Mr Trichet called on the US to take action to reduce its budget deficit and restore confidence in the economy.

"It is crucially important for the global economy, and in particular for the United States, that initiatives be taken in order to improve the long-term perspectives as regards budgetary discipline and growth," he said.

'No exchange rate target'

Earlier this week, US Treasury Secretary Henry Paulson sought to play down fears of a currency war, saying the dollar's value would be determined by the strength of the US economy.

On Wednesday, EU finance ministers issued a statement urging the US to take "decisive action" to cut its deficit and stop the dollar's decline.

Mr Trichet said the ECB would not intervene in the foreign exchange markets to prop up the dollar.

"We don't have any exchange rate target," he said. "We have only one objective, which is to maintain price stability."

The European Union is set to lift its arms embargo on China, according to diplomats.

The move, which still needs final approval, would end a ban imposed after the 1989 Tiananmen Square crackdown.

It comes amid concerns that the EU is losing its influence with Beijing as the US "pivots" towards Asia.

China has reacted angrily to US moves to station troops in Asia and strengthen alliances there.

The EU arms embargo was imposed in response to the Chinese military's violent suppression of pro-democracy protests in Tiananmen Square in 1989.

Since then, the EU has been gradually softening its stance, and in 2005 it lifted a ban on selling non-lethal military equipment to China.

'Losing out'

The latest move would end the embargo completely, and would allow EU countries to sell weapons to China for the first time in more than two decades.

It is not yet clear when the embargo will be lifted, but diplomats say it could happen as early as next month.

The BBC's Chris Morris in Brussels says the move is likely to anger human rights campaigners, who argue that the EU should not be doing business with a country with such a poor record.

But our correspondent says the EU is keen to improve relations with China, and is worried about losing out as the US "pivots" towards Asia.

The US has been trying to reassert its influence in the region, and has been stationing troops in Asia and strengthening alliances there.

China has reacted angrily to the US moves, and has been trying to increase its own influence in the region.

The EU is China's biggest trading partner, and the two sides have been working on a free trade agreement for several years.

Microsoft plans to introduce a new system that it says will make it harder for criminals to steal people's identities.

At the moment, people have to remember a different user name and password for each site.

Microsoft said the new system would be more secure because it would use two-factor authentication.

This means that as well as a password, the user would also need a physical device, such as a mobile phone, to log in.

The company said the system would also make it easier for people to manage their online identities.

"We want to make it so that people don't have to think about their identity when they're online," said Microsoft's chief privacy officer, Brendon Lynch.

UK Coal has reported a bigger annual loss after being hit by falling coal prices and production problems.

'Significant challenges'

UK Coal is the country's largest coal producer, and supplies about 6% of the coal used in power stations.

It said the fall in coal prices had been driven by a combination of factors, including a mild winter, which reduced demand, and increased competition from cheaper gas.

The company's production was also hit by a fire at its Daw Mill mine in Warwickshire in July, which forced its closure.

The fire caused about £40m of damage, and the company said it would not reopen the mine.

UK Coal said it was taking steps to cut costs, including reducing the number of its employees by about 10%.

It is also selling some of its non-core assets, and is in talks with the government about the possibility of converting some of its mines to produce gas.

"The group faces significant challenges," said chief executive Kevin McCullough.

Defeated mayoral candidate Zac Goldsmith has said he was not personally "leant on" by the Conservative Party to resign his seat and causes a by-election.

Announcing his resignation on Thursday, Mr Goldsmith said he could not "ignore" the views of those who had voted to leave the EU.

But he said he would not support a Labour candidate - expected to be confirmed later as Sadiq Khan - in the by-election, expected to take place on 9 June.

"My problem is not with the Conservative Party, it is with the government," he said, adding that he would continue to support the Conservatives "from the back benches".

Two US men who ran a popular online piracy site have been convicted of conspiracy and copyright infringement.

Jeremy Aures and Jesse Terrell ran TVShack.net, which provided links to illegal copies of TV shows and movies.

They were convicted by a federal jury in North Carolina after a five-day trial.

Aures and Terrell now face up to five years in prison and a $250,000 fine when they are sentenced in March.

US prosecutors said TVShack.net had more than seven million unique visitors in 2010 and earned advertising revenue of at least $150,000 (£93,000).

The website allowed users to find illegal copies of TV shows and movies that had been uploaded to file-sharing sites such as MegaUpload.

"The defendants knowingly profited from massive online piracy, costing copyright holders millions of dollars," said US Assistant Attorney General Lanny Breuer.

"This prosecution sends a strong message that the Justice Department will hold accountable those who unlawfully profit from the creative efforts of others."

Aures' lawyer, Richard Levitt, said his client was "disappointed" with the verdict and would appeal.

"We think the government's case was overstated and that the defendants' actions were less culpable than the government alleged," he said.

Terrell's lawyer, Michael DiLauro, said he was "surprised and disappointed" by the jury's decision.

The US government has been cracking down on online piracy in recent years.

In January 2012, the Department of Justice shut down the file-sharing site MegaUpload and indicted its founder, Kim Dotcom, on racketeering and copyright infringement charges.

Car demand surges

South African car demand surged in November after the government cut interest rates and vehicle prices fell.

A total of 43,937 vehicles were sold last month, up from 36,895 in October, the National Association of Automobile Manufacturers of South Africa (Naamsa) said.

"This is the second-highest monthly total on record and well above expectations," said Naamsa director Nico Vermooten.

It was also the sixth consecutive month of growth in the South African car market.

Naamsa said the sales were boosted by a cut in interest rates announced by the South African Reserve Bank last month, as well as falling vehicle prices.

"With the continuation of these positive trends, we expect the market to maintain its upward momentum in the months ahead," said Mr Vermooten.

Last month, South Africa's two biggest carmakers - Volkswagen and Toyota - reported record sales.

Volkswagen said it had sold 9,282 vehicles in November, up from 7,065 in the same month a year earlier.

Toyota said its sales rose by 16% to 9,172 vehicles.

Gigapixel pictures are giant images made up of billions of pixels. They are so big that you can zoom in and see tiny details that you couldn't see in a normal photo.

To make a gigapixel picture, you need to start with a very high-resolution image. This could be a photo that's been taken with a very high-resolution camera, or a photo that's been stitched together from many smaller photos.

Once you have your high-resolution image, you need to use software to divide it up into billions of tiny squares, each one just a few pixels wide.

Then, you need to use a special camera to take millions of photographs of these tiny squares. This can be a regular digital camera, but it needs to be mounted on a robotic platform so that it can take lots of photos quickly and accurately.

Finally, you need to use software to stitch all of these photos together into a single gigapixel image. This process can take days or even weeks, depending on the size of the image.

Gigapixel pictures are already being used by Google Earth and Microsoft's Bing Maps, and they are becoming increasingly popular with amateur photographers.

George Osborne will deliver his first Budget as chancellor on 16 March, Downing Street has confirmed.

The announcement comes after Prime Minister David Cameron reshuffled his cabinet on Tuesday, making Mr Osborne joint first secretary of state.

No 10 said this meant he would attend cabinet "as of right" and co-ordinate economic policy across Whitehall.

Labour called it a "panic measure" which showed the government was "in chaos".

'Economic honeymoon'

BBC political correspondent Iain Watson said the date for the Budget - which had been widely trailed in the media - was significant as it was the Ides of March, the day Julius Caesar was assassinated.

Downing Street said the fact that Mr Osborne was being made joint first secretary of state - a title he will share with William Hague - reflected the "importance" the prime minister attached to economic policy.

Ministers attending cabinet "as of right" do not have to be approved by the Queen, as all other members do.

It means, our correspondent adds, that Mr Osborne will have a free hand in setting the economic agenda without having to concern himself with the feelings of other cabinet ministers.

A source close to the chancellor said: "This is part of the process of ensuring that, as we move out of the economic honeymoon period and into the really tough decisions about deficit reduction, the decisions are being made in the round by the government."

'End to coalition'

Labour has accused the Conservatives of trying to distance themselves from the Lib Dems in the run-up to local and devolved elections in May.

Shadow chancellor Alan Johnson said: "This is a panic measure which exposes the government for what it is - a coalition in chaos.

"George Osborne attending cabinet 'as of right' is the final act in the slow motion car crash that this coalition has become.

"The Conservatives wanted this coalition and they wanted the Lib Dems to take the blame for the tough decisions they are making.

"Today's move demonstrates that plan has failed and the country is now seeing the true colours of the Tories."

But Lib Dem MP Jeremy Browne - the foreign office minister responsible for South East Asia and the Pacific - tweeted: "Those who think coalition is over or that Lib Dems are a spent force are mistaken. We continue to punch above our weight."

The UK film industry has experienced a significant decline in production, with a 40% drop reported in 2021, according to the British Film Institute (BFI). This sharp decrease is largely attributed to the ongoing impact of the Covid-19 pandemic, which has disrupted filming schedules and led to the closure of cinemas nationwide.

The BFI's annual report revealed that only 188 films went into production in the UK last year, compared to 314 in 2020, marking the lowest number since records began. The total spend on film production also fell by 21% to £1.3bn, down from £1.6bn in 2020.

The pandemic has had a profound impact on the film industry, with social distancing measures and lockdowns forcing many productions to halt or delay filming. The closure of cinemas has also led to a significant loss of revenue, with many films being released directly to streaming platforms instead.

Despite the challenges, the BFI report highlighted some positive trends. High-end television production, which includes shows made for streaming platforms like Netflix and Amazon, increased by 11% to a record £2.3bn. This suggests a shift in consumer behaviour, with more people choosing to watch content at home rather than in cinemas.

The report also noted that the UK film industry is showing signs of recovery. The number of films going into production in the second half of 2021 was almost double that of the first half, indicating that the industry is beginning to adapt to the new challenges posed by the pandemic.

Ben Roberts, CEO of the BFI, said: "Despite the significant challenges of the past year, the resilience and creativity of the UK film industry have been truly remarkable. We are optimistic about the future and believe that with the right support, the industry can bounce back stronger than ever."

The UK government has introduced a £500m film and TV production restart scheme to help the industry recover. The scheme provides compensation for productions that have been halted or delayed due to Covid-19.

However, industry experts warn that the recovery will be slow and uneven, with many smaller production companies struggling to survive. They are calling for more government support to ensure the long-term sustainability of the UK film industry.

In a significant development, no charges will be filed against the renowned television personality, Bill Cosby, according to the latest reports. The decision comes after a thorough investigation into multiple allegations of sexual assault against the actor.

After several months of a worldwide supply glut and decreased demand due to the COVID-19 pandemic, prices of crude oil have rebounded significantly. Global benchmark, Brent Crude, and the US standard, West Texas Intermediate (WTI), both sit convincingly above $50 per barrel, marking a significant economic turning point amidst a struggling world economy.

The WTI, more sensitive to the conditions of the US market, now stands at $52.25 per barrel, while Brent Crude, representing worldwide prices, stands at $53.75 per barrel, showcasing an unparalleled surge beyond $50 after months of deprivation.

This recovery in oil prices is significant as it reflects increasing confidence in global economic recovery and expectations of a potential uptick in demand as the distribution of COVID-19 vaccines engenders a return to a semblance of normalcy.

The oil price had plummeted in 2020 due to a drop in demand as numerous countries went into lockdown. The international demand for oil fell as airplanes were grounded, factories closed, and millions around the world worked from home.

Market analysts attribute this rebound to multiple factors. "The introduction of vaccines uplifted the sentiments in the crude oil market, stimulating investors' optimism about future demand," says Jason Feer, head of business intelligence at Poten & Partners. "Add in Saudi Arabia's surprise announcement to cut production by 1 million barrels per day in February and March, The U.S. economic stimulus and a weak US dollar, and we have a perfect recipe for an oil price increase."

Many experts still remain cautious, warning that new variations of the virus still pose threats to the recovering economy and there is a potential for another price collapse. "The current increase in prices should be viewed with caution until a consistent global recovery is in sight," warns energy analyst, Frederic Larson.

Nonetheless, the current surge in prices is certainly welcome news for oil producers and exporting countries, as well as industries reliant on oil prices. It provides a glimmer of hope for a fluctuating market that has taken several hits due to the global pandemic and a struggling world economy.

The future of wireless internet connectivity is set to take a giant leap forward with the development of next-generation Wi-Fi technology, promising faster speeds, greater capacity, and improved performance.

The new technology, known as Wi-Fi 6E, is expected to revolutionise the way we connect to the internet, offering speeds up to three times faster than the current Wi-Fi 6. This souped-up version of Wi-Fi is designed to cope with the increasing demand for high-speed internet in our homes and workplaces, as more devices become internet-enabled and data-heavy activities like streaming and gaming become more prevalent.

Wi-Fi 6E operates on a higher frequency band than previous versions, which allows for faster data transmission and less congestion. This means that more devices can connect to the network at the same time without slowing down the overall speed. 

The Wi-Fi Alliance, the global network of companies that drives the adoption of Wi-Fi worldwide, has already begun certifying devices for Wi-Fi 6E. This means that consumers can expect to see routers, smartphones, laptops, and other devices equipped with this new technology hitting the market in the near future.

"Wi-Fi 6E will bring remarkable improvements in wireless performance," said Edgar Figueroa, CEO of the Wi-Fi Alliance. "It will support the growing number of connected devices, provide greater bandwidth for data-intensive applications, and pave the way for new innovations in technology."

However, the rollout of Wi-Fi 6E will not be without challenges. The higher frequency band it operates on, known as the 6GHz band, is currently used by other services such as satellite links and radar systems. This means that regulatory approval will be needed in many countries before Wi-Fi 6E can be widely adopted.

Despite these hurdles, the potential benefits of Wi-Fi 6E are significant. With the ongoing global pandemic forcing many people to work and study from home, the demand for reliable, high-speed internet has never been greater. Wi-Fi 6E could be the solution to this problem, providing a faster, more stable connection for everyone.

In conclusion, while it may still be some time before Wi-Fi 6E becomes commonplace, its potential to transform our digital lives is undeniable. As we continue to rely more heavily on the internet for work, education, and entertainment, the arrival of souped-up Wi-Fi is a development that is eagerly anticipated.

Mr. Ebbers denied all accusations, underscoring his unawareness about the $11bn (£5.7bn) accounting fraud during his time as WorldCom's CEO.

Standing trial in New York, Ebbers pleaded not guilty to charges of fraud and conspiracy. If convicted, the charges could lead to a 25-year prison term for the 63-year-old. He is chiefly accused of being instrumental in inflating WorldCom's assets by about $11bn, eventually leading to the company's bankruptcy in 2002. 

In his defense, Ebbers emphasised his lack of expertise in accounting. His lawyer, Reid Weingarten, echoed the claims stating, "Bernie Ebbers never sought to mislead investors, never sought to improperly manipulate Worldcom's numbers, never improperly took any money and never sought to hurt the company he built."

The prosecution team, however, countered this defense by presenting former WorldCom financial director, Scott Sullivan, as their star witness. Sullivan, who pleaded guilty to his part in the fraud in 2004, testified that Ebbers had a clear understanding of the financial situation and was closely involved in the decisions leading to the accounting scandal.

The collapse of WorldCom was the largest bankruptcy in U.S. history. It cost around 20,000 jobs, leaving shareholders out of pocket by almost $180bn.

WorldCom, now rebranded as MCI, has since been bought by telecoms giant Verizon. The audit failure at the company led to significant changes in U.S. regulatory laws with the introduction of the Sarbanes-Oxley Act, aimed at tightening corporate accountability.

The trial continues.

Former UK Conservative Party leader, Michael Howard, has revealed that he used to skip school to play snooker. The confession came during an interview on BBC Radio 4's Desert Island Discs, where he admitted to being a "bit of a tearaway" in his youth.

Mr. Howard, who led the Conservative Party from 2003 to 2005, said he would often sneak off to a local snooker hall in Llanelli, South Wales, instead of attending school. He described his younger self as "not a very good boy" and admitted that his truancy was a "terrible thing to do".

The former Home Secretary, now 79, said he was "captivated" by the game of snooker from a young age. He recalled how he would spend hours at the snooker hall, honing his skills and trying to perfect his game.

"I was absolutely captivated by snooker," he said. "I would spend hours and hours in the snooker hall when I should have been at school. It was a terrible thing to do and I wouldn't recommend it to anyone."

Despite his truancy, Mr. Howard went on to have a successful political career. He served as Home Secretary under John Major's government from 1993 to 1997 and later led the Conservative Party, although he failed to win the 2005 general election.

Mr. Howard's love for snooker has not waned over the years. He is a regular at the World Snooker Championships in Sheffield and has often spoken about his passion for the game.

During the radio interview, he also spoke about his early life, his political career, and his love for music. He chose tracks by Elvis Presley, Frank Sinatra, and the Beatles for his desert island playlist.

The former Tory leader's confession about his school days has sparked a debate about truancy and the importance of education. While some have criticised Mr. Howard for his actions, others have argued that his story shows that unconventional paths can also lead to success.

Mr. Howard ended the interview by saying, "I was lucky. I got away with it. But I wouldn't advise anyone to follow my example."

Cybersecurity firms have sounded an alarm over the increasing number of domain system scams, raising fears of huge financial losses and a breach of personal data. 

Unsuspecting internet users and businesses have been targeted by fraudsters asking for bank information or tricking them by 'spoofing' transactions for the transfer of domain names. Typically, scammers send an email often disguised as coming from a credible source, like the domain registrar or internet service provider, to get users to reveal sensitive personal or financial data.

"Scammers have become advanced and are now able to make their emails and websites appear genuine," says cybersecurity expert, Mr. Thomas Moore. "Those unfamiliar with such tricks easily fall victim, potentially causing tremendous financial loss and breach of personal information."

Experts warn that the level of sophistication used by scammers has significantly increased over the past years. They are reportedly using similar sounding domain names, logos and even addresses of legitimate businesses to trick their victims.

The Internet Corporation for Assigned Names and Numbers (ICANN), which oversees the global domain name system, has also expressed its concerns. It claims that these scams are undermining the trust of internet users and threatening online transactions.

"As much as we are working hard to regulate the digital landscape, users need to be cautious about the emails they receive and the websites they visit," says an ICANN spokesperson. "Not all issues can be solved technically, end-users being vigilant is equally crucial."

In addition to the financial losses, the rising numbers of domain system scams also pose a significant risk regarding data protection. Personal or financial information intercepted by scammers could lead to identity theft and fraud.

Authorities urge individuals and businesses to practice safe online behavior. This includes regularly updating antivirus software, double-checking sender email addresses, never providing financial or personal information without verifying the source and regularly changing passwords.

Security experts are also advising business owners to register similar sounding or spelled domain names to their business to prevent scammers from creating counterfeit domains.

Regulators worldwide are now prioritizing actions to battle these cybercrimes, however, the onus also lies on internet users to remain informed and vigilant against potential domain system scams in the digital realm.

In an increasingly digital world, the importance of writing secure and accurate code is escalating rapidly. With an array of sectors from finance to healthcare becoming dependent on coding, guidelines for ethical and professional behaviour in programming have become essential.

This article does not serve as a warning against the acquisition of programming skills. On the contrary, it underlines how essential these skills have become in the current job market. Coding has become an indispensable part of a variety of sectors, not just in IT but in education, marketing, analytics, and many more. However, as Spiderman's Uncle Ben once famously said, "With great power, comes great responsibility."

Coding language forms the backbone of our digital world. A myriad of devices functions through code - the websites we browse, the mobile applications we use, the wearable tech we sport, everything is a product of coding.

Hence, a mistake in the coding process could result in dire consequences – from compromising users’ sensitive data to causing complete systems breakdown. There have been many instances where faulty coding has led to significant losses. The 2015 Starbucks incident is a striking example where a bug in the system led to customers being overcharged. On a more threatening scale, a security vulnerability could expose millions of users' data to malicious hackers.

A key point here is not just errors but the deliberate misuse of coding skills. Codes can be manipulated to create malicious software and viruses that have the potential to harm individuals and organisations greatly. Cybersecurity breaches are increasingly becoming more insidious and complex under the hands of skilled programmers.

It’s vital that coding is undertaken responsibly. Best practices should always be observed, including testing and checking the code rigorously before launch, patching and updating it regularly. Programmers should be ethical about the kind of programs they write, ensuring they don’t create software that infringes on privacy or poses unnecessary risks.

Programmers also have a responsibility to continue learning and improving their skills to ensure they remain up-to-date with advancements in technology and the latest safety protocols. 

The tech industry needs to address these issues and provide better training to ensure safer coding practices. Programming should be taught alongside lessons in ethics and responsibility, ensuring future coders understand the potential harm negligent or malicious coding can cause.

In short, those who code hold a high level of power in this digital age. But, with this power, they must also recognize and take seriously the responsibility they have. Careful and ethical coding is not just recommended in today's world; it is a requirement.

Argentina has successfully closed a deal to swap $102.6bn in debt, a move that is aimed at averting a damaging default and bringing the South American nation one step closer to economic stability. 

The Argentine government announced the deal on Monday, labeling it a significant moment in the country's efforts to tackle the long-standing issue of hit-or-miss payments on its external debt. Following months of negotiations with private creditors, the government confirmed that it had crossed the 90% acceptance mark needed to move forward with the swap deal.

The renegotiation of debt has been a cornerstone of President Alberto Fernández’s economic strategy since taking office in December. Seeking to avoid a ninth sovereign debt default, the administration had proposed an ambitious restructuring plan that invited bondholders to exchange their current holdings for new bonds that would pay less and mature later.

"This pact confirms the support and trust of our foreign investors and the international community," said Martin Guzman, Argentina's Economy Minister. "It lifts a huge burden from our shoulders and charts a clear path towards economic recovery."

Argentina's debt saga began in 2001 when it defaulted on nearly $100 billion, leading to years of legal battles with holdout creditors. Since then, the South American nation has been characterized by its precarious economy, underscored by rampant inflation, a fall in the currency, and dwindling foreign reserves.

The agreement is seen as remarkable in economic circles given that it was reached amid the global shock caused by the pandemic. Dire predictions of a prolonged debt standoff, which many expected would lead to a hard default and deepen the country's economic pain, have been avoided. 

International Monetary Fund's Managing Director, Kristalina Georgieva, applauded the agreement, stating that it will provide Argentina with substantial debt relief. “This is a very, very significant step forward,” Georgieva said. “Not just for Argentina but also contributing positively to the stability of the international financial system.”

Despite this positive development, Argentina still faces daunting economic challenges on the horizon. The administration will now begin talks to renegotiate about $44 billion it borrowed from the International Monetary Fund in 2018, the largest loan package in the IMF's history.

This recent milestone marks a decisive resurrection for Argentina and sends out a strong signal to foreign investors that the country is willing to take serious steps to manage their financial situation. But the road to economic recovery remains long and steep, particularly under the shadow of the Coronavirus pandemic. The government will need to build upon this success with consistent fiscal policies that foster growth and investor confidence.

Germany's unemployment rate has hit a new record low, according to the latest figures from the Federal Employment Agency. The jobless rate has now fallen to 4.9% in a trend that reflects positively on the strength of Europe's biggest economy.

Analysts had previously predicted this figure, but the milestone endorses Germany's economic stability amid global economic uncertainties, demonstrating potential resilience in the face of international headwinds.

Approximately 2.23 million people were unemployed in Germany last month, the lowest figure recorded since reunification in 1990. This figure is 185,000 fewer than the same period last year and corresponds to a decline of more than 8%.

The report also highlighted an increase in job vacancies, with around 798,000 open positions reported in April, approximately 6,000 more than during the previous month and 32,000 more than the same period the previous year.

"The German labour market continues to develop robustly," said Detlef Scheele, the head of the Federal Employment Agency. "Despite a moderate economic development, demand for labour continues to be very high."

Economists assert that Germany´s robust labour market, backed by strong domestic demand, could provide a buffer against potential negative external impacts. These impacts include potential trade uncertainties from Brexit and global trade disputes, as well as slower global economic growth.

Although the economy contracted in the third quarter of 2019 and narrowly avoided a recession by posting zero growth in the fourth, Germany’s labour market remained resilient. The strong labour market, record-high employment and rising wages are fuelling a domestically-driven growth upswing, making private consumption an important growth driver.

However, despite such a robust labour market, many businesses in the country have reported facing a shortage of skilled workers. The Association of German Chambers of Commerce and Industry warned last year that the lack of skilled workers could become an increasing problem for Europe's largest economy and could potentially limit its future growth.

In a tight labour market, economists usually expect wages to rise, fuelling inflation and eventually prompting the European Central Bank (ECB) to hike interest rates. However, wage growth has remained relatively subdued in Germany, keeping inflation in check and allowing the ECB to maintain loose monetary policy.

A new technology utilizing lasers is being implemented to connect devices in areas with poor or non-existent internet connectivity, bridging the gap for those previously disconnected from the digital world.

In remote regions where traditional networking infrastructure is unavailable or unreliable, laser-based connections are providing a reliable and efficient means of communication. By harnessing the power of light, these systems use lasers to transmit data through free space, allowing devices to communicate with one another without the need for physical cables or cellular networks.

The technology works by using small, low-power lasers to create narrow beams of light that can travel long distances and penetrate through obstacles such as trees or buildings. These beams are then received by photodetectors, which convert the light signals back into electrical signals that can be interpreted by devices.

One company at the forefront of this technology is LightPointe, whose products have been used to establish high-speed connections between buildings and even mountain tops. Their systems can transmit data at speeds of up to 10 Gbps (gigabits per second), making them ideal for applications such as video streaming, online gaming, and cloud computing.

"Our technology has the potential to revolutionize the way we connect devices," said John Smith, CEO of LightPointe. "Not only does it provide fast and reliable connectivity, but it also eliminates the need for expensive and time-consuming infrastructure development."

Another benefit of laser-based connections is their security. Unlike radio waves, which can be intercepted or jammed, light signals are difficult to detect and intercept, making them virtually immune to eavesdropping and interference. They also had to overcome technical challenges such as latency and server capacity to ensure that all 210 messages were delivered successfully within the one-minute time frame.

However, the achievement serves as a demonstration of the advancements that can be made in messaging technology, and paves the way for future innovations in communication.

The rapid rise in popularity of gadgets such as smartphones and tablet computers has led to an increase in electronic waste, according to new research.

A study by Greenpeace found that 10% of all mobile phones sold last year were replaced within six months.

It said this was partly due to consumers being encouraged to upgrade their devices more frequently than necessary.

Greenpeace called on manufacturers to make products easier to repair or recycle.

'E-waste'

The report - Toxic Twist: How Mobile Phone Companies are Poisoning Our Planet - looked at how much energy it took to produce and dispose of mobile phones and other portable electronics.

It also examined the amount of hazardous chemicals used during production and whether they could be recycled easily when no longer needed.

According to the report, the average lifespan of a phone is now just two years, compared with four years for older models.

This means that there will be about one billion handsets discarded each year over the next five years, it added.

In addition, the number of tablets sold worldwide rose from zero in 2009 to almost 75 million units in 2011.

However, only around 30% of these devices can currently be reused or recycled, while many contain toxic substances including lead, mercury and cadmium.

"We have seen a huge surge in sales of mobile phones and tablets," said Gary Cook, senior IT analyst at Greenpeace International.

"But we need to ask ourselves if we really want to see our planet covered in mountains of e-waste."

He added: "Manufacturers must take responsibility for what happens to their products after they leave the shop floor."

Mr Cook urged companies to use less harmful materials in their manufacturing processes and design products so that they could be repaired or upgraded rather than thrown away.

Apple, Samsung and Nokia among those criticised

Sony said its Cell Broadband Engine would also allow for new types of gameplay that could not previously have been imagined.

It added that the chip was designed with future technologies in mind.

However, analysts say the PS3 may struggle against rival consoles because of its price tag.

The Cell chip - developed jointly by IBM, Toshiba and Sony - contains eight processing cores, each capable of running independently or together as one unit.

This means that while one core can run an operating system, another can play a game, and yet another can display video content on screen.

In addition, the chip includes a graphics engine based on Nvidia technology, which allows for more realistic images than those seen on current generation machines such as Microsoft's Xbox 360 and Nintendo's Wii.

Sony said this meant that developers would be able to create games that were far more immersive than anything currently available.

For example, they might include real-time weather effects, or even let players interact with other people online without having to leave their living room.

"We believe that our next-generation console will offer users unprecedented levels of entertainment," said Kaz Hirai, president of Sony Computer Entertainment America (SCEA).

"With the introduction of the Cell Broadband Engine we are taking gaming into a whole new realm."

Analysts say that although the PS3 looks set to be a powerful machine, it faces stiff competition from rivals who already have established user bases.

Microsoft launched its Xbox 360 last year, while Nintendo released its Wii earlier this month. Both devices cost less than £250 ($479), compared with around £425 ($800) for the PS3.

It is no secret that smart phones are an inviting target for hackers and the world's cyber police.

"We have seen a spike in the last few months of spy/surveillance products coming on the market to target smart phones," said Dell SecureWorks Inc. threat researcher Paul Henry.

As reported by the New York Times, spyware on smart phones can be used to:

· turn on the microphone to listen in on a room
· turn on the camera for continuous photo-taking
· capture the contents of the phone such as phone numbers and address book
· intercept phone call data
· intercept text messages

Mr Henry said spyware was becoming so common that it has given rise to new hacker-oriented "malvertising" services that can infect a smart phone simply by clicking on an advertisement. "This is pretty sophisticated stuff," Mr Henry said. "It is just like a zombie computer. It can capture anything the phone sees and send it anywhere in the world." The best way to avoid infection is always to be cautious about what you agree to when prompted by popup windows. As we have noted in previous posts, do not download any apps from dubious or unknown sources.

The Chinese government has delayed its approval for MG Rover to sell cars in China, BBC business correspondent Joe Lynam reports from Beijing.

China's Ministry of Commerce had been expected to give final clearance this week but it now appears that will not happen until next month at the earliest.

It means any deal with Shanghai Automotive Industry Corporation (SAIC) could be further delayed.

A spokesman said SAIC was still interested in buying MG Rover and talks were continuing.

"We are still negotiating," he told Reuters news agency.

But he added that there would be no comment on whether or when an agreement might be reached.

Earlier this year, SAIC agreed to buy 51% of MG Rover for £20m ($37m).

However, the deal has yet to go through because of delays over the sale of assets by the car maker's administrators PricewaterhouseCoopers (PwC).

In particular, PwC have been unable to find buyers for two plants which make engines and gearboxes.

They also want to ensure that all outstanding debts owed to suppliers are paid before they can hand control of the company to SAIC.

BBC business editor Robert Peston says that while the delay may seem like bad news for MG Rover, it does mean that the company will continue to receive funding from the UK taxpayer.

The internet has become an essential part of our lives, but it's not always easy for everyone to get online.

In some parts of the world there are no fixed-line connections and mobile data can be expensive or unreliable.

But now a new technology called Long Term Evolution (LTE) could help bring high speed wireless access to more people than ever before.

It promises download speeds up to 10 times faster than current 3G networks - and that means you can do things like watch TV on your phone without having to wait ages for the video to buffer.

So how does LTE work? And what will it mean for us in the future?

## What is LTE?

Long Term Evolution is a standard developed by the telecommunications industry body known as the Third Generation Partnership Project (3GPP). It was first introduced commercially in Sweden back in December 2009.

There are two main types of LTE network: FDD (Frequency Division Duplexing), which uses different frequencies for uploading and downloading; and TDD (Time Division Duplexing), where both functions share the same frequency band.

Both versions use orthogonal frequency division multiplexing (OFDM) modulation techniques to send information over radio waves at much higher rates than previous technologies such as GSM and UMTS/WCDMA.

This allows them to carry far greater amounts of traffic while still maintaining good quality voice calls.

The Beastie Boys have won the first major test of a controversial British Copyright Act which makes it easier for performers to take control of their sampled recordings.
Judge Andrew Smith has ruled that the American group's record label Grand Royal can control future uses of the drum loop to 'Funky Drummer' by Clyde Stubblefield.
Last year, Grand Royal won a High Court case against the MCA group, which owned Stubblefield's recording. MCA then lodged an appeal.
Beasties sample
The Beastie Boys use a sample of 'Funky Drummer' for their 1989 hit 'Paul Revere' from their album Paul's Boutique.
The Beastie Boys say they bought a licence from the American producer of the track. But Stubblefield took MCA to court over his royalties. It was then that MCA challenged Grand Royal's ownership of the drum loop.
The Beastie Boys, who claim they are fighting for freedom of music makers, argued that they bought a licence in good faith. MCA however says Stubblefield was never paid for the work on 'Funky Drummer'.
Judge Smith said: "If this were strictly an issue of the interpretation of the licence agreement, it might be said that Stubblefield's interest in the matter is at an end because of the sale of his interests in the music to MCA.
"However, in my judgement there is a right of action against the subsequent user of the recording, Grand Royal, for unauthorised copying."
Judge Smith ordered MCA to pay Grand Royal's legal costs and to hand over its copies of the drum loop. He also ordered Grand Royal to pay MCA's legal costs.

US actor Ossie Davis, best known for his role in the classic film "Do the Right Thing," has been found dead at the age of 87.

Davis, who was also a civil rights activist, passed away on Friday at his home in New York City, according to police sources. The cause of death has not yet been determined.

Davis' career spanned six decades and included numerous stage, television and film appearances. In addition to "Do the Right Thing," he was also known for his roles in "Cotton Club," "The Big Easy" and "Jungle Fever."

Davis was awarded numerous honors for his work in entertainment and civil rights, including the National Medal of Arts and the Presidential Medal of Freedom.

His wife, actress Ruby Dee, released a statement saying, "I am devastated by the loss of my beloved husband Ossie. He was a great man, an incredible artist and an activist to the end."

Davis is survived by his wife and their two children. Funeral arrangements have not yet been announced.

Chelsea winger Arjen Robben has reportedly been denied a move to Barcelona by Blues boss Frank Lampard, according to reports in Spain.

Robben's future at Stamford Bridge has been uncertain this summer with his contract set to expire next year and interest from LaLiga champions Barca. However, it is understood that Lampard wants to keep the Dutch international at Chelsea for another season.

The 34-year-old joined Chelsea from Real Madrid in 2009 and has won two Premier League titles during his time in west London. He also helped the club reach the Champions League final last season, where they were defeated by Arsenal.

Despite being linked with a move away from Chelsea, Robben has hinted that he could still stay at the club beyond this season. "I don't know what will happen," he said earlier this month. "We'll see how things go."

Barcelona have already signed Atlético Madrid midfielder Antoine Griezmann as part of their rebuilding process under new coach Ronald Koeman. They are also believed to be interested in signing Manchester City forward Sergio Agüero, although negotiations over a potential transfer appear to have stalled.

George Galloway, former Respect Party leader and current Member of Parliament for Bradford West, has launched an attack on one of his fellow MPs who he claims is part of “New Labour”. In a fiery speech delivered in Westminster yesterday, Mr. Galloway singled out Imran Hussain, the MP for Wakefield, accusing him of being too close to Prime Minister Tony Blair’s government.

Mr. Galloway accused Mr. Hussain of betraying his constituents by voting in favor of controversial bills such as the Anti-Terrorism Crime and Security Act, which many critics argue undermines civil liberties. He also criticized Mr. Hussain for failing to speak out against Britain's involvement in the Iraq War.

In response to Mr. Galloway's accusations, Mr. Hussain defended his record as an MP, stating that he has always acted in the best interests of his constituency and has consistently opposed policies that he believes are wrong. However, he acknowledged that there may be differences between himself and Mr. Galloway on certain issues.

The feud between the two MPs has been brewing for some time, with Mr. Galloway previously describing New Labour as a "fascist" organisation. Yesterday's speech was seen by many observers as an attempt by Mr. Galloway to widen his campaign against what he sees as the excesses of the current government.

In a landmark case that has far-reaching implications for the world of sport, a top athlete has been banned from competition for using performance-enhancing drugs.

The athlete in question is none other than Sarah Collins, a former world champion and one of the most recognizable faces in her sport. Collins, who has been suspended for four years, has admitted to taking a banned substance in a bid to improve her performance.

The decision to ban Collins, who has also been stripped of all her results from the relevant period, has been welcomed by anti-doping organizations, who have long called for tougher penalties for athletes caught cheating.

Collins's ban is the latest in a series of high-profile cases involving doping in sport, and underscores the ongoing struggle to ensure fair play and maintain the integrity of competition.

The case also highlights the importance of rigorous drug testing and the need for athletes to be aware of the risks associated with using performance-enhancing drugs.

Collins, who has yet to comment on the ruling, is likely to appeal the decision, but in the meantime, her absence from competition is sure to have a significant impact on her sport, and on the athletes who will now have to step up to fill the void left by one of its most dominant figures.

In an unprecedented admission, JP Morgan has acknowledged that it profited from slavery in the United States during the 19th century. The banking giant said it had discovered through research that its predecessor firms played a role in financing the slave trade and supporting plantations that relied on forced labor. 

The revelation comes as part of a growing movement among companies to examine their histories for any ties to slavery or other forms of exploitation. Many corporations have found such connections despite efforts over decades or even centuries to distance themselves from these dark chapters in American history.

"We recognize that our predecessors were involved in activities that were morally wrong and diametrically opposed to our company's values today," Jamie Dimon, CEO of JPMorgan Chase & Co., said in a statement. "As we've studied our own history, we've found instances where our firm and its predecessors were connected to aspects of this shameful period."

JPMorgan specifically cited two New York-based banks that merged with it in the late 1800s: the Manhattan Company and the Mercantile National Bank. Both institutions financed Southern plantation owners who depended on enslaved laborers, according to the bank's analysis.

While there is no doubt that many businesses benefited from the institution of slavery, few have been willing to confront their past head-on like JPMorgan has done. The acknowledgment represents a significant step towards confronting America's complicated relationship with race and wealth.

The legendery actor was offered the part of Don Vito Corleone by director Francis Ford Coppola but ultimately declined, citing creative differences with the script and his dissatisfaction with the film industry at large.

Despite this rejection, the role eventually went to Brando's friend Marcello Mastroianni, who won an Academy Award for Best Supporting Actor for his portrayal of Carlo Rizzi in 1982.

These revelations came from author William Wright's new book “Playboy: The Life & Art of Hugh Hefner,” which offers insight into the discussions surrounding the making of the classic movie.

Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair has said he is "up for it" ahead of a planned poll to elect a new leader for his party, the Labour Party.

Mr. Blair, who led the party to three election victories before stepping down in 2007, is expected to run for the position. He has been widely criticized for his decision to support the Iraq War, but has also been praised for his work in improving the National Health Service.

In an interview with the BBC, Mr. Blair said he was "very confident" about his chances and that he believed he had the support of the party membership. He also said that he would focus on issues such as poverty and inequality if elected.

The election is expected to take place later this year, with current Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn facing challenges from several other candidates.

It was a hot day at Wimbledon, but the temperature didn't seem to affect Marat Safin as he cruised into the third round with a straight sets victory over German qualifier Benjamin Becker.

Safin, who is known for his volatile on-court temperament, appeared to be in a calm and collected mood as he dispatched Becker 6-3, 6-4, 6-4 in just over two hours.

The Russian, who won the tournament in 2000, will face either Argentine Juan Ignacio Chela or Frenchman Fabrice Santoro in the next round.

Elsewhere on Centre Court, fourth seed Lleyton Hewitt of Australia was made to work hard before beating Slovakian Dominik Hrbaty 7-6, 7-6, 6-3.

Hewitt, who is seeking his first Wimbledon title, saved two set points in the first set before going on to win a tight encounter that lasted just under three hours.

In the women's draw, top seed and defending champion Serena Williams advanced to the third round with a 6-1, 6-2 victory over Slovakia's Daniela Hantuchova.

Williams, who is seeking her fourth Wimbledon title, looked in impressive form as she raced into a 5-0 lead in the first set and never looked back.

In other second round action, fifth seed Amelie Mauresmo of France was made to work hard before beating American Meghann Shaughnessy 6-3, 6-7, 9-7, while sixth seed Justine Henin-Hardenne of Belgium had little trouble in beating Italy's Flavia Pennetta 6-1, 6-2.

The UK Government has announced plans to strip British citizenship from individuals suspected of involvement in terrorism, making it easier for them to be deported to their country of origin. The move comes amid growing concerns over extremism and the radicalization of young people in Britain. Home Secretary Sajid Javid said that the proposal was designed to help tackle the threat posed by jihadist ideologies and ensure that those who pose a risk to national security cannot use British citizenship as a shield. Critics, however, have described the policy as "draconian" and questioned its constitutional validity, with some arguing that it could lead to innocent people being wrongly deprived of their nationality. Amnesty International also warned that the measure would set a dangerous precedent for other countries around the world looking to crack down on dissent and opposition. Whether the proposed law will pass through parliament remains uncertain at this stage, but if approved, it is likely to face legal challenges before coming into effect.

Ireland produced a thrilling comeback to defeat Argentina 21-19 in a tightly contested Rugby Union International match at the Aviva Stadium in Dublin.

Trailing 19-14 with just seven minutes remaining, Ireland scored a crucial try through full-back Rob Kearney to secure a memorable victory.

Argentina had taken an early lead through a penalty from fly-half Nicolas Sanchez, but Ireland hit back with tries from lock Iain Henderson and centre Garry Ringrose.

Sanchez added two more penalties to give Argentina a 12-10 half-time lead, but Ireland took the lead with a penalty from Johnny Sexton before Sanchez replied with a penalty of his own.

Argentina looked to have secured the win when winger Santiago Cordero crossed for a try, but Ireland's late rally proved decisive.

The victory will be a huge boost for Ireland ahead of their Rugby World Cup campaign, which gets underway in September.

Independent record labels are set to benefit from new technology that will allow them to sell their music directly to fans through digital downloads, it has been announced. The development comes as part of efforts to level the playing field between independent and major labels, who have traditionally had greater access to distribution channels.

The new system allows independents to upload their tracks onto an online platform, where they can then be purchased by customers. Revenue generated from these sales will be split fairly between the label and the artist involved, with both receiving a larger share than would typically be the case through traditional retail outlets.

According to industry experts, this move could revolutionize the way in which independent artists distribute their work, giving them more control over their creative output and potentially increasing their earnings. It is hoped that the initiative will also help to support smaller labels, many of which struggle to compete against the financial clout of multinational corporations.

Speaking about the announcement, one independent label owner praised the move as "a game-changer" for the sector, while another described it as "long overdue". They added that the ability to sell direct to consumers was crucial in an increasingly crowded market, where securing shelf space or airtime could be difficult.

Details of the scheme were unveiled at a conference aimed at promoting the interests of independent musicians and labels. Delegates heard how the platform - due to launch later this year - aims to provide a simple and cost-effective solution for those looking to reach a wider audience without relying on traditional intermediaries.

While some critics have expressed concerns about the potential impact on established retailers, supporters of the plan argue that it offers a vital lifeline to talented but overlooked artists. They hope that the increased exposure and revenue opportunities provided by the platform will encourage further innovation and creativity within the indie community.

British shoppers have demonstrated their Christmas spirit with strong retail sales figures, according to latest data released by the Office for National Statistics (ONS).

The ONS revealed that in November, UK high streets and shopping centres saw an increase of 4% compared to last year's figures, marking the strongest growth since March this year.

Experts attribute this surge in spending to consumers' eagerness to kick-start celebrations after months of restrictions due to the pandemic, as well as retailers offering attractive discounts ahead of the holiday season.

Brick-and-mortar stores witnessed significant footfall during the month, while online sales also rose by 2%, indicating a broad-based recovery across various sectors of the economy.

Clothing and footwear shops recorded the highest spike in sales at 8.7%; however, other categories such as food, drink, and household goods also registered substantial gains.

While these numbers are encouraging signs of consumer confidence bouncing back, experts caution against reading too much into one month's worth of data, especially given ongoing concerns about rising infections and tighter lockdown measures in some parts of the country.

Nonetheless, the robust performance of retail sales is likely to provide further evidence that Britain's economic recovery remains on track despite the challenges posed by COVID-19.

England head coach Eddie Jones has confirmed that fly-half Owen Farrell will miss the remainder of the Six Nations after suffering a dislocated elbow in the defeat to Ireland.

Farrell, who has been England's standout player in the tournament so far, was forced off in the second half of the loss to Ireland on Saturday and scans have revealed the extent of the injury.

Jones has named George Ford as Farrell's replacement for the remaining matches against Scotland and Wales, with the tournament hosts currently sitting second in the table on four points.

"It's a big loss for us, Owen's been playing really well," Jones said. "But we've got depth in the squad and George has been playing well for Bath this season."

England will be hoping to bounce back from the defeat to Ireland when they face Scotland at Murrayfield on February 24.

LONDON (BBC) - The soaring price of crude oil is having an increasingly devastating impact on global economic growth, according to experts.
The cost of Brent Crude has risen by more than 50% in just over a year and now stands at around $85 per barrel. This increase comes as countries struggle with inflationary pressures caused by Russia's invasion of Ukraine and supply chain disruptions due to COVID-19.
Analysts warn that this surge could lead to higher fuel prices for consumers, which would further exacerbate already high levels of inflation across many economies. Additionally, rising energy costs are likely to hit industries such as transportation, manufacturing, and construction hard, potentially leading to job losses and reduced investment.
While some governments have attempted to mitigate these effects through stimulus packages or subsidies, there are concerns about the long-term sustainability of such measures. Many economists believe that urgent action is needed to address the root causes of the crisis, including investing in renewable energies and improving energy efficiency.
In addition, geopolitical tensions between major producers like the US and China continue to escalate, raising fears of potential disruption to supplies. As a result, several international organizations have downgraded their forecasts for global GDP growth this year.
Overall, analysts say that while short-term fluctuations in commodity markets are always possible, the current situation represents a significant challenge to the stability and prosperity of the global economy.

Liverpool and England midfielder Michael Owen is expected to be named as captain of his country's football team in the near future, according to reports on Thursday. 

The 23-year-old has been widely tipped to succeed Tony Adams as armband holder following the former Arsenal defender's shock resignation from international duty last month.
  
Although there have been no official announcements yet over who will fill the void left by Adams, sources close to manager Sven Goran Eriksson suggest that he already knows whom he wants to lead out the Three Lions during tomorrow night's friendly against Australia at Newcastle's St James' Park stadium.
 
   Should those whispers prove accurate then it would bring an end to decades of debate among English soccer aficionados about which current player deserves such recognition - with many arguing either Manchester United striker Alan Shearer or Chelsea midfield general Dennis Wise should take up the mantle instead.

Manchester United could face a potential sixth-round FA Cup clash with League Two side Stockport County after they were drawn together in the fifth round of the competition.

The National League side, who are currently 11th in the table, pulled off a shock by beating Championship side Rotherham United 2-1 at Edgeley Park on Saturday to book their place in the next round.

If United, who are currently second in the Premier League, were to beat Shrewsbury Town in their fifth-round tie later this month, they would face Stockport in a mouth-watering clash at Old Trafford.

The potential tie has been dubbed as the "Bee-atles" clash, with both teams having bee emblems in their crests.

Stockport manager Jim Gannon, who played for United in the 1990s, said: "It would be a fantastic draw for us if we were to get Manchester United at home.

"We know it would be a tough game but we have nothing to lose and everything to gain. We will go there and give it a right good go."

United manager Ole Gunnar Solskjaer said: "We know it's going to be tough, but we'll go there to win the game."

In a move that could spark a bidding war, Qwest Communications International has made an offer to acquire MCI Inc, a rival telecommunications company. The offer, worth approximately $14.8 billion, was made public on Monday.

If the deal goes through, it would create the second-largest telecommunications company in the United States, behind only AT&T. Qwest's offer is higher than the $14 billion offer made by Verizon Communications earlier this year, which was rejected by MCI.

MCI's board of directors has formed a special committee to review Qwest's offer and determine the best course of action for the company. It is unclear at this time whether Qwest's offer will be accepted or if other companies may enter the bidding war.

The telecommunications industry has been undergoing significant changes in recent years, with many companies seeking to consolidate in order to cut costs and remain competitive. This latest development could further shake up the industry and lead to more mergers and acquisitions in the future.

The controversial hunting season has begun in England and Wales, with hunt supporters determined to push for their rights despite recent bans being lifted. The Hunting Act 2004 made it illegal to hunt wild mammals with dogs but exemptions were granted for foxes, which are considered vermin, and hares on certain conditions.

However, animal welfare campaigners have expressed concerns over how these exceptions will be enforced, fearing that hunts may still cause distress to protected species such as deer or horses. They also argue that there is no scientific evidence proving that hunting helps control pest populations.

In response, pro-hunt groups claim they follow strict guidelines laid out by the governing bodies and insist that all participants undergo training before taking part in any activities. Supporters say this sport provides an important tradition within rural communities while others see it as cruel and unnecessary practice.

As hunters take to fields across country today, police forces have warned that anyone found flouting the law could face prosecution. It remains unclear whether enforcement officers would prioritize investigating complaints related to non-exempted animals like rabbits during ongoing debates surrounding legality and morality of traditional British pastime.
